# Indo-Pakistani War of 1971

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to navigation Jump to search

Indo-Pakistani War of 1971  
---  
Part of the [Indo-Pakistani wars and conflicts](/wiki/Indo-
Pakistani_wars_and_conflicts "Indo-Pakistani wars and conflicts") and
[Bangladesh Liberation War](/wiki/Bangladesh_Liberation_War "Bangladesh
Liberation War")  
[![1971 Instrument of
Surrender.jpg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/1971_Instrument_of_Surrender.jpg/335px-1971_Instrument_of_Surrender.jpg)](/wiki/File:1971_Instrument_of_Surrender.jpg)  
[Lieutenant-General](/wiki/Lieutenant-General "Lieutenant-General") [A. A. K.
Niazi](/wiki/A._A._K._Niazi "A. A. K. Niazi"), the commander of [Pakistan
Eastern Command](/wiki/Pakistan_Eastern_Command "Pakistan Eastern Command"),
signing the [instrument of surrender](/wiki/Pakistani_Instrument_of_Surrender
"Pakistani Instrument of Surrender") in [Dhaka](/wiki/Dhaka "Dhaka") on 16 Dec
1971, in the presence of India's [Lt. Gen. Jagjit Singh
Aurora](/wiki/Jagjit_Singh_Aurora "Jagjit Singh Aurora"). Standing immediately
behind from Left to Right: Indian Navy [Vice Admiral
Krishnan](/wiki/Nilakanta_Krishnan "Nilakanta Krishnan"), Indian Air Force
[Air Marshal Dewan](/wiki/Hari_Chand_Dewan "Hari Chand Dewan"), Indian Army
[Lt Gen Sagat Singh](/wiki/Sagat_Singh "Sagat Singh"), [Maj Gen JFR
Jacob](/wiki/J._F._R._Jacob "J. F. R. Jacob") (with Flt Lt Krishnamurthy
peering over his shoulder). Veteran newscaster, Surojit Sen of [All India
Radio](/wiki/All_India_Radio "All India Radio"), is seen holding a microphone
on the right.  
| Date | 3–16 December 1971 (13 days)  
---|---  
Location | Eastern Front:

  * [India–East Pakistan border](/wiki/India%E2%80%93East_Pakistan_border "India–East Pakistan border")
    * [Bay of Bengal](/wiki/Bay_of_Bengal "Bay of Bengal")
    * [Pasha enclaves](/wiki/India%E2%80%93Bangladesh_enclaves "India–Bangladesh enclaves")

Western Front:

  * [India–Pakistan border](/wiki/Indo-Pakistani_border "Indo-Pakistani border")
    * [Line of Control](/wiki/Line_of_Control "Line of Control")
    * [Arabian Sea](/wiki/Arabian_Sea "Arabian Sea")

  
Result | Decisive Indian victory.[1][2][3]  
**Eastern front:**  
[Surrender of East Pakistan military
command](/wiki/Instrument_of_Surrender_\(1971\) "Instrument of Surrender
\(1971\)").  
**Western front:**  
Unilateral Ceasefire.[4]  
Territorial  
changes |  Eastern Front:

  * Independence of East Pakistan as [Bangladesh](/wiki/Bangladesh "Bangladesh")

Western Front:

  * Indian forces captured around 5,795 square miles (15,010 km2) land in the West but returned it in the [Simla Agreement](/wiki/Simla_Agreement "Simla Agreement") as a gesture of goodwill.[5][6][7]

The **Indo-Pakistani War of 1971** was a military confrontation between
[India](/wiki/India "India") and [Pakistan](/wiki/Pakistan "Pakistan") that
occurred during the [liberation war](/wiki/Bangladesh_Liberation_War
"Bangladesh Liberation War") in [East Pakistan](/wiki/East_Pakistan "East
Pakistan") from 3 December 1971 to the [fall of
Dacca](/wiki/Pakistani_Instrument_of_Surrender "Pakistani Instrument of
Surrender") ([Dhaka](/wiki/Dhaka "Dhaka")) on 16 December 1971. The war began
with [preemptive aerial strikes](/wiki/Operation_Chengiz_Khan "Operation
Chengiz Khan") on 11 [Indian air
stations](/wiki/List_of_Indian_Air_Force_stations "List of Indian Air Force
stations") that led to the commencement of hostilities with Pakistan and
Indian entry into the [war of independence](/wiki/Bangladesh_War_of_Liberation
"Bangladesh War of Liberation") in East Pakistan on the side of [Bengali
nationalist forces](/wiki/Bangladesh_Forces "Bangladesh Forces"). Lasting just
13 days, it is one of the shortest wars in history.[24][25]

During the war, Indian and Pakistani militaries simultaneously clashed on the
eastern and western front and ended the war after the [Eastern
Command](/wiki/Pakistan_Eastern_Command "Pakistan Eastern Command") of
[Pakistan military](/wiki/Pakistan_Armed_Forces "Pakistan Armed Forces")
signed the [Instrument of Surrender](/wiki/Instrument_of_Surrender_\(1971\)
"Instrument of Surrender \(1971\)")[26] on 16 December 1971 in Dhaka, marking
the [formation](/wiki/Independence_of_Bangladesh "Independence of Bangladesh")
of East Pakistan as the new nation of [Bangladesh](/wiki/Bangladesh
"Bangladesh"). Officially, East Pakistan had earlier called for its secession
from the [unity](/wiki/Unity,_Faith,_Discipline "Unity, Faith, Discipline") of
Pakistan on 26 March 1971. Approximately 90,000[27] to 93,000 Pakistani
servicemen were [taken prisoners](/wiki/Indo-
Pakistani_War_of_1971_Prisoners_of_War_Investigation "Indo-Pakistani War of
1971 Prisoners of War Investigation") by the [Indian Army](/wiki/Indian_Army
"Indian Army"), which included 79,676 to 81,000 uniformed personnel of the
Pakistan Armed Forces, including some Bengali soldiers who had remained loyal
to Pakistan.[27][28][29] The remaining 10,324 to 12,500
[prisoners](/wiki/Prisoner_of_war "Prisoner of war") were civilians, either
family members of the military personnel or collaborators
([razakars](/wiki/Razakar_\(Pakistan\) "Razakar
\(Pakistan\)")).[27][30][31][32] It is estimated that between 300,000 and
3,000,000 civilians were killed in Bangladesh.[33][34][35][36][37] As a result
of the conflict, a further eight to ten million people fled the country to
seek refuge in India.[38] During the 1971 [Bangladesh war for
independence](/wiki/Bangladesh_Liberation_War "Bangladesh Liberation War"),
members of the [Pakistani military](/wiki/Pakistan_Armed_Forces "Pakistan
Armed Forces") and supporting [Islamist](/wiki/Islamism "Islamism")
[militias](/wiki/Militia "Militia") from Jamaat e Islami [raped](/wiki/Rape
"Rape") between 200,000 and 400,000 [Bangladeshi](/wiki/Bangladeshis
"Bangladeshis") women and girls in a systematic campaign of [genocidal
rape](/wiki/Genocidal_rape "Genocidal rape").[39][40][41][42]

## Background[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Indo-
Pakistani_War_of_1971&action=edit&section=1 "Edit section: Background")]

Main articles: [Cable 1971](/wiki/Cable_1971 "Cable 1971"), [Admiral Ahsan
Mission](/wiki/Admiral_Ahsan_Mission "Admiral Ahsan Mission"), [Bangladesh
Liberation War](/wiki/Bangladesh_Liberation_War "Bangladesh Liberation War"),
[Mukti Bahini](/wiki/Mukti_Bahini "Mukti Bahini"), [1971 Bangladesh
atrocities](/wiki/1971_Bangladesh_atrocities "1971 Bangladesh atrocities"),
[Timeline of Bangladesh Liberation
War](/wiki/Timeline_of_Bangladesh_Liberation_War "Timeline of Bangladesh
Liberation War"), and [1971 Bangladesh
genocide](/wiki/1971_Bangladesh_genocide "1971 Bangladesh genocide")

The Indo-Pakistani conflict was sparked by the armed liberation struggle that
was taking place in [East Pakistan](/wiki/East_Pakistan "East Pakistan")
between the dominant [Bengalis](/wiki/Bangladeshi_people "Bangladeshi people")
and the [multi-ethnic](/wiki/Demographics_of_Pakistan "Demographics of
Pakistan") West [Pakistanis](/wiki/Pakistani_people "Pakistani people") over
the issue of [right to governance](/wiki/Right_to_govern "Right to govern")
and the [constitution](/wiki/Constitution_of_Pakistan "Constitution of
Pakistan").[43]:24[19] The political tensions between [East
Bengal](/wiki/East_Bengal "East Bengal") and West Pakistan had its origin in
the times of the [creation of Pakistan](/wiki/Independence_of_Pakistan
"Independence of Pakistan") as a result of the [partition of
India](/wiki/Partition_of_India "Partition of India") by the [United
Kingdom](/wiki/United_Kingdom "United Kingdom") in 1947, the popular [language
movement](/wiki/Bengali_language_movement "Bengali language movement") in
1950, [mass riots](/wiki/1964_East_Pakistan_riots "1964 East Pakistan riots")
in East Bengal in 1964, and eventually massive protests in 1969 that
eventually led to the resignation of [President](/wiki/President_of_Pakistan
"President of Pakistan") [Ayub Khan](/wiki/Ayub_Khan_\(President_of_Pakistan\)
"Ayub Khan \(President of Pakistan\)"), who invited [army
chief](/wiki/Army_Chief_of_Staff_\(Pakistan\) "Army Chief of Staff
\(Pakistan\)") General [Yahya Khan](/wiki/Yahya_Khan "Yahya Khan") to take
over the [central government](/wiki/Government_of_Pakistan "Government of
Pakistan").[44]:xxx The geographical distance between the eastern and western
wings of Pakistan was vast, as East Pakistan was over 1,000 miles (1,600 km)
away, which greatly hampered any attempt to integrate the [Bengali
culture](/wiki/Culture_of_Bangladesh "Culture of Bangladesh") with the
[cultures](/wiki/Culture_of_Pakistan "Culture of Pakistan") of West
Pakistan.[45]:13–14[46][_[self-published
source](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability#Self-published_sources
"Wikipedia:Verifiability")_]:xxi

To overcome the Bengali domination and prevent them from their right to form
the central government in [Islamabad](/wiki/Islamabad "Islamabad"), the
controversial [One Unit](/wiki/One_Unit "One Unit") program was promulgated
which established the two wings of East and [West
Pakistan](/wiki/West_Pakistan "West Pakistan"), but such efforts were met with
great opposition from the West Pakistanis. This made it difficult to
effectively govern both wings.[44]:xxx In 1969, President Yahya Khan announced
the first [general elections](/wiki/Elections_in_Pakistan "Elections in
Pakistan") and he [disestablished the status
of](/wiki/Legal_Framework_Order,_2002 "Legal Framework Order, 2002") West
Pakistan as a single province in 1970 in order to restore it to its original
heterogeneous status comprising [four
provinces](/wiki/Four_Provinces_\(Pakistan\) "Four Provinces \(Pakistan\)"),
as defined at the time of establishment of Pakistan in 1947.[47] In addition,
there were also religious and racial tensions between Bengalis and the multi-
ethnic West Pakistanis, as Bengalis looked different from the dominant West
Pakistanis.[43]:24–25

The [general elections](/wiki/Pakistani_general_election,_1970 "Pakistani
general election, 1970"), held in 1970, resulted in East Pakistan's [Awami
League](/wiki/Awami_League "Awami League") gaining 167 out of 169 seats for
the [East Pakistan Legislative
Assembly](/wiki/East_Pakistan_Legislative_Assembly "East Pakistan Legislative
Assembly"), and a near-[absolute majority](/wiki/Supermajority
"Supermajority") in the 313-seat [National
Assembly](/wiki/National_Assembly_of_Pakistan "National Assembly of
Pakistan"), while the [vote](/wiki/Vote_bank "Vote bank") in West Pakistan was
mostly won by the [socialist](/wiki/Socialism_in_Pakistan "Socialism in
Pakistan") [Pakistan Peoples Party](/wiki/Pakistan_Peoples_Party "Pakistan
Peoples Party").[48]:686–687 The Awami League leader [Sheikh Mujibur
Rahman](/wiki/Sheikh_Mujibur_Rahman "Sheikh Mujibur Rahman") stressed his
political position by presenting his [Six Points](/wiki/Six_point_movement
"Six point movement") and endorsing the Bengalis' right to govern.[44]:xxx The
Awami League's election success caused many West Pakistanis to fear that it
would allow the Bengalis to draft the constitution based on the six-points and
liberalism.[49]:xlv

To resolve the crisis, the [Ahsan–Yaqub Mission](/wiki/Admiral_Ahsan_Mission
"Admiral Ahsan Mission") was formed to provide insightful recommendations, and
its findings were met with favourable reviews from the Awami League, the
Pakistan Peoples Party, and the Pakistan Muslim League as well as from
President Yahya Khan.[50]:109–110

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Historical_Pakistan.gif/250px-
Historical_Pakistan.gif)](/wiki/File:Historical_Pakistan.gif)

[](/wiki/File:Historical_Pakistan.gif "Enlarge")

Maps shows Pakistan and East Pakistan.Distance between East and Pakistan laid
1,000 miles (1,600 km) of [Indian territory](/wiki/Geography_of_India
"Geography of India").

However, the mission was not supported by the elements in the [National
Security Council](/wiki/National_Security_Council_\(Pakistan\) "National
Security Council \(Pakistan\)") and was subsequently vetoed.[50]:110 After
[Zulfikar Ali Bhutto](/wiki/Zulfikar_Ali_Bhutto "Zulfikar Ali Bhutto"), the
chairman of Pakistan Peoples Party, endorsed the veto and subsequently refused
to yield the [premiership](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Pakistan "Prime Minister of
Pakistan") of Pakistan to Sheikh Mujibur Rahman, the Awami League called for
general strikes in the country.[50]:110 President Yahya Khan postponed the
inauguration of the National Assembly and this caused a shattering
disillusionment to the Awami League and their supporters throughout East
Pakistan.[51] In reaction, Sheikh Mujibur Rahman called for general strikes
that eventually [shutdown](/wiki/Government_shutdown "Government shutdown")
the government, and dissidents in the East began targeting the ethnic Bihari
community which had supported West Pakistan.[52]

In early March 1971, approximately 300 Biharis were slaughtered in riots by
Bengali mobs in [Chittagong](/wiki/Chittagong "Chittagong") alone.[53] The
Government of Pakistan used the "Bihari massacre'" to justify its deployment
of the military in East Pakistan on 25 March, when it initiated its [military
crackdown](/wiki/Operation_Searchlight "Operation Searchlight").[54]
[President](/wiki/President_of_Pakistan "President of Pakistan") Yahya Khan
then called on the military - which was overwhelmingly led by West Pakistanis
- to suppress dissent in the East, after accepting the resignation of
[Lieutenant-General](/wiki/Lieutenant_general "Lieutenant general") [Yaqub Ali
Khan](/wiki/Sahabzada_Yaqub_Khan "Sahabzada Yaqub Khan"), the chief of staff
of the [East-Pakistani military](/wiki/Bangladesh_Armed_Forces "Bangladesh
Armed Forces").[55][56]

Mass arrests of dissidents began and after several days of strikes and [non-
cooperation movement](/wiki/Non-cooperation_movement "Non-cooperation
movement"), the Pakistani military led by [Tikka Khan](/wiki/Tikka_Khan "Tikka
Khan") cracked down on Dhaka on the night of 25 March 1971. The Awami League
was outlawed by the government, and many of its members and sympathizers took
refuge in [Eastern India](/wiki/Eastern_India "Eastern India"). Mujib was
arrested on the night of 25/26 March 1971 at about 1:30 am (as per Radio
Pakistan's news on 29 March 1971) and taken to West Pakistan. The next action
carried out was [Operation Searchlight](/wiki/Operation_Searchlight "Operation
Searchlight") followed by [Operation Barisal](/wiki/Operation_Barisal
"Operation Barisal"), in an attempt to kill the intellectual elite of the
east.[57]

On 26 March 1971, [Major](/wiki/Major "Major") [Ziaur
Rahman](/wiki/Ziaur_Rahman "Ziaur Rahman") of Pakistan Army declared the
independence of Bangladesh on behalf of Sheikh Mujibur Rahman.[58][59][60]

In April, the exiled Awami League leaders formed a [government-in-
exile](/wiki/Provisional_Government_of_Bangladesh "Provisional Government of
Bangladesh") in [Baidyanathtala](/wiki/Mujibnagar "Mujibnagar") of
[Meherpur](/wiki/Meherpur "Meherpur"). The [East Pakistan
Rifles](/wiki/East_Pakistan_Rifles "East Pakistan Rifles") and Bengali
officers in Pakistan's [army](/wiki/Pakistan_Army "Pakistan Army"),
[navy](/wiki/Pakistan_Navy "Pakistan Navy"), and
[marines](/wiki/Pakistan_Marines "Pakistan Marines"),
[defected](/wiki/Defector "Defector") to the rebellion after taking refuge in
different parts of India. The Bangladesh Force, namely the [Mukti
Bahini](/wiki/Mukti_Bahini "Mukti Bahini"), consisting of Niyomito Bahini
(Regular Force) and Oniyomito Bahini ([Guerilla](/wiki/Guerrilla_warfare
"Guerrilla warfare") Force), was formed under the retired colonel [Mohammad
Ataul Gani Osmani](/wiki/MAG_Osmani "MAG Osmani")[61]

## India's involvement in Bangladesh Liberation
War[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Indo-Pakistani_War_of_1971&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: India's involvement in Bangladesh Liberation War")]

Main articles: [1971 East Pakistan genocide](/wiki/1971_East_Pakistan_genocide
"1971 East Pakistan genocide"), [Terrorism in
Pakistan](/wiki/Terrorism_in_Pakistan "Terrorism in Pakistan"), and [Anti-
Pakistan sentiment](/wiki/Anti-Pakistan_sentiment "Anti-Pakistan sentiment")

After the resignations of [Admiral](/wiki/Admiral "Admiral") [S.M.
Ahsan](/wiki/Syed_Mohammad_Ahsan "Syed Mohammad Ahsan") and Lieutenant-General
Yaqub Ali Khan, the [media correspondents](/wiki/Media_reporting_team "Media
reporting team") began airing reports of the Pakistani military's [widespread
genocide](/wiki/1971_East_Pakistan_genocide "1971 East Pakistan genocide")
against their Bengali citizens,[62] that was particularly aimed at the
minority [Bengali Hindu](/wiki/Bengali_Hindus "Bengali Hindus")
population,[63][64][24] which led to approximately 10 million people seeking
refuge in the neighbouring states of Eastern India.[63][62][65] The [Indian
government](/wiki/Indian_government "Indian government") opened the [East
Pakistan–India border](/wiki/Bangladesh%E2%80%93India_border "Bangladesh–India
border") to allow the [Bengali refugees](/wiki/East_Bengali_refugees "East
Bengali refugees") to take safe shelter, with state governments of [West
Bengal](/wiki/Government_of_West_Bengal "Government of West Bengal"),
[Bihar](/wiki/Government_of_Bihar "Government of Bihar"),
[Assam](/wiki/Government_of_Assam "Government of Assam"),
[Meghalaya](/wiki/Government_of_Meghalaya "Government of Meghalaya") and
[Tripura](/wiki/Government_of_Tripura "Government of Tripura") establishing
[refugee camps](/wiki/Refugee_camp "Refugee camp") alongside the
border.[66]:23–24 The resulting flood of impoverished East Pakistani refugees
placed an intolerable strain on India's already overburdened economy.[64]

After the war, the Pakistan Army's generals in the East held each other
responsible for the atrocities committed, but most of the burden was laid on
Lieutenant-General [Tikka Khan](/wiki/Tikka_Khan "Tikka Khan"), who earned
notoriety from his actions as governor of the East; he was called the "Butcher
of Bengal" because of the widespread atrocities committed under his
responsibility.[67] Unlike his contemporary Yaqub who was a
[pacifist](/wiki/Pacifism "Pacifism") and knew well of the limits of force,
Tikka was a "soldier known for his eager use of force" to settle his
differences.[68]:100[69][70][71]

Confessing at the hearings of the [War Enquiry
Commission](/wiki/Hamoodur_Rahman_Commission "Hamoodur Rahman Commission"),
Lieutenant-General [A.A.K. Niazi](/wiki/Amir_Abdullah_Khan_Niazi "Amir
Abdullah Khan Niazi") reportedly commented on Tikka's actions and noted: "On
the night between 25/26 March 1971, [General] Tikka struck. Peaceful night was
turned into a time of wailing, crying and burning. [General] Tikka let loose
everything at his disposal as if raiding an enemy, not dealing with his own
misguided and misled people. The military action was a display of stark
cruelty more merciless than the massacres at [Bukhara](/wiki/Bukhara
"Bukhara") and [Baghdad](/wiki/Baghdad "Baghdad") by [Chengiz
Khan](/wiki/Chengiz_Khan "Chengiz Khan") and [Halaku Khan](/wiki/Hulagu_Khan
"Hulagu Khan")... [General] Tikka... resorted to the killing of civilians and
a [scorched earth](/wiki/Scorched_earth "Scorched earth") policy. His orders
to his troops were: "I want the land, not the people..."."[72][_[self-
published source](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability#Self-published_sources
"Wikipedia:Verifiability")_]:295 [Major-General](/wiki/Major-General "Major-
General") [Rao Farman](/wiki/Rao_Farman_Ali "Rao Farman Ali") had written in
his table diary: "Green land of East Pakistan will be painted red. It was
painted red by Bengali blood."[73] However, Major-General Farman had
forcefully denied writing that comment, and laid all responsibility on Tikka,
while confessing at the War Enquiry Commission in 1974.[74]

The [Indian government](/wiki/Government_of_India "Government of India")
repeatedly appealed to the [international
community](/wiki/International_community "International community"), but
failed to elicit any response, despite the [External Affairs
minister](/wiki/Minister_of_External_Affairs_\(India\) "Minister of External
Affairs \(India\)") [Swaran Singh](/wiki/Swaran_Singh "Swaran Singh") meeting
foreign ministers of other countries.[75] Prime Minister [Indira
Gandhi](/wiki/Indira_Gandhi "Indira Gandhi") on 27 March 1971 expressed full
support of her government for the independence struggle of the people of East
Pakistan, and concluded that instead of taking in millions of refugees, it was
economical to go to war against Pakistan.[65] On 28 April 1971, the [Gandhi
cabinet](/wiki/First_Indira_Gandhi_ministry "First Indira Gandhi ministry")
had ordered the [Chief of the Army
Staff](/wiki/Chief_of_the_Army_Staff_\(India\) "Chief of the Army Staff
\(India\)") General [Sam Manekshaw](/wiki/Sam_Manekshaw "Sam Manekshaw") to
"Go into East Pakistan".[76][77][78] Defected East Pakistan military officers
and the elements of Indian [Research and Analysis
Wing](/wiki/Research_and_Analysis_Wing "Research and Analysis Wing") (RAW)
immediately started using the Indian refugee camps for recruitment and
training of [Mukti Bahini](/wiki/Mukti_Bahini "Mukti Bahini")
[guerrillas](/wiki/Guerrilla "Guerrilla") that were to be trained against
Pakistan.[79] In 1971, there was a strong wave of Indian-supported Bangladeshi
nationalism in the East. The situation became violent and the systematic
[targeted killings](/wiki/Targeted_killings_in_Pakistan "Targeted killings in
Pakistan") of unarmed multi-ethic Pakistanis living in the East
started.[80]:164 [Vehicle bombings](/wiki/Car_bombings "Car bombings") on
government secretariats became a normal narrative, and [high-profile
assassinations](/wiki/Abdul_Monem_Khan "Abdul Monem Khan") of a number of
those Bengali politicians who were loyal to Pakistan, became common in the
East.[80]:164 According to [Jussi Hanhimäki](/wiki/Jussi_Hanhim%C3%A4ki "Jussi
Hanhimäki"), [Finnish](/wiki/Finland "Finland") historian of terrorism, the
Bengali terrorism in the East is a somewhat "forgotten episode of annals of
terrorism."[80]:164 The [Hamoodur Rahman
Commission](/wiki/Hamoodur_Rahman_Commission "Hamoodur Rahman Commission")
endorsed the claims of Bengali terrorism when it critically penned that the
ill-treatment of families of multi-ethnic Pakistanis led to the [Pakistani
military soldiers](/wiki/Pakistan_Armed_Forces "Pakistan Armed Forces")
[reacting](/wiki/Revenge "Revenge") violently in order to restore the writ of
the government.[81]

The [news media](/wiki/News_channels_in_Pakistan "News channels in
Pakistan")'s mood in Pakistan had also turned increasingly
[jingoistic](/wiki/Jingoism "Jingoism") and militaristic against East Pakistan
and India when the Pakistani news media reported the complexity of the
situation in the East, though the reactions from Pakistan's news media pundits
were mixed.[82][83] By the end of September 1971, an organised
[propaganda](/wiki/Propaganda "Propaganda") campaign, possibly orchestrated by
elements within the [Government of Pakistan](/wiki/Government_of_Pakistan
"Government of Pakistan"), resulted in stickers proclaiming _Crush India_
becoming a standard feature on the rear windows of vehicles in
[Rawalpindi](/wiki/Rawalpindi "Rawalpindi"), [Islamabad](/wiki/Islamabad
"Islamabad") and [Lahore](/wiki/Lahore "Lahore"); this soon spread to the rest
of West Pakistan.[84] By October, other stickers proclaimed _Hang the Traitor_
, in an apparent reference to Sheikh Mujibur Rahman.[85] By the first week of
December, the conservative [print media](/wiki/Newspapers_in_Pakistan
"Newspapers in Pakistan") outlets in the country had published
_[jihad](/wiki/Jihad "Jihad")_ related materials to boost the recruitment in
the military.[84]

## India's official engagement with Pakistan[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Indo-
Pakistani_War_of_1971&action=edit&section=3 "Edit section: India's official
engagement with Pakistan")]

### Objective[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Indo-
Pakistani_War_of_1971&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section: Objective")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Bangladesh_1971_Liberation.jpg/250px-
Bangladesh_1971_Liberation.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bangladesh_1971_Liberation.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Bangladesh_1971_Liberation.jpg "Enlarge")

Illustration showing military units and troop movements during operations in
the Eastern sector of the war.

By the end of April 1971, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi had asked the Indian
Army chief General Sam Manekshaw if he was ready to go to war with
Pakistan.[86][87] According to Manekshaw's own personal account, he refused,
citing the onset of [monsoon season](/wiki/Monsoon_in_India "Monsoon in
India") in East Pakistan and also the fact that the army tanks were in the
process of being refitted.[88] He offered his resignation, which Gandhi
declined.[88] He then said he could guarantee victory if she would allow him
to prepare for the conflict on his terms, and set a date for it; Gandhi
accepted his conditions.[89][90] In reality, Gandhi was well aware of the
difficulties of a hasty military action, but she needed to get the military's
views to satisfy her hawkish colleagues and the public opinion, which were
critical of India's restraint.[78]

By November 1971, the war seemed inevitable and the [Soviet
Union](/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet Union") reportedly [warned Pakistan against
the war](/wiki/Rodionov_message "Rodionov message"), which they termed as
"suicidal course for Pakistan's unity."[91]:part-3 Throughout November 1971,
there were thousands of people led by conservative Pakistani politicians who
marched in Lahore and across Pakistan, calling for Pakistan to _Crush
India_.[92][93] India responded by starting a massive buildup of the Indian
Army on the western borders; the army waited until December, when the drier
ground would have made for easier operations and the
[Himalayan](/wiki/Himalayas "Himalayas") passes would have been closed by
snow, preventing any Chinese intervention.[94]:174–175 On 23 November,
President Yahya Khan declared a [state of emergency](/wiki/State_of_emergency
"State of emergency") in all of Pakistan and told his people to prepare for
war.[95]

On the evening of 3 December, at about 5:40 pm,[96] the [Pakistan Air
Force](/wiki/Pakistan_Air_Force "Pakistan Air Force") (PAF) launched surprise
[pre-emptive strikes](/wiki/Operation_Chengiz_Khan "Operation Chengiz Khan")
on eleven airfields in north-western India, including [Agra](/wiki/Agra
"Agra"), which was 300 miles (480 km) from the border.[97]:82–83 At the time
of this attack the [Taj Mahal](/wiki/Taj_Mahal "Taj Mahal") was camouflaged
with a forest of twigs and leaves and draped with burlap, because its marble
glowed like a white beacon in the moonlight.[98]

This preemptive strikes, known as [Operation Chengiz
Khan](/wiki/Operation_Chengiz_Khan "Operation Chengiz Khan"), were inspired by
the success of Israeli [Operation Focus](/wiki/Operation_Focus "Operation
Focus") in the [Arab](/wiki/Arab "Arab")–Israeli [Six-Day War](/wiki/Six-
Day_War "Six-Day War"), but unlike the Israeli attack on Arab airbases in 1967
which involved a large number of Israeli planes, Pakistan flew no more than 50
planes to India.[97]:82[99]

In an address to the nation on radio that same evening, Prime Minister Gandhi
held that the air strikes were a declaration of war against India[100][101]
and the [Indian Air Force](/wiki/Indian_Air_Force "Indian Air Force") (IAF)
responded with initial air strikes that very night.[4] These air strikes were
expanded to massive retaliatory air strikes the next morning.[4]

This marked the official start of the Indo-Pakistani War of 1971; Prime
Minister Gandhi ordered the immediate mobilisation of troops and launched a
full-scale invasion of Pakistan.[102]:333 This involved Indian forces in
massive [coordinated air](/wiki/East_Pakistan_Air_Operations,_1971 "East
Pakistan Air Operations, 1971"), sea and land assaults on Pakistan from all
fronts.[102]:333 The main Indian objective on the Eastern front was to capture
Dacca, and on the Western front was to prevent Pakistan from entering Indian
soil.[96] There was no Indian intention of conducting any major offensive into
Pakistan to dismember it into different states.[96]

### Naval hostilities[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Indo-
Pakistani_War_of_1971&action=edit&section=5 "Edit section: Naval
hostilities")]

Main article: [Indo-Pakistani Naval War of 1971](/wiki/Indo-
Pakistani_Naval_War_of_1971 "Indo-Pakistani Naval War of 1971")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Ussdiablo.jpg/250px-
Ussdiablo.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ussdiablo.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Ussdiablo.jpg "Enlarge")

Pakistan's [PNS  _Ghazi_](/wiki/PNS_Ghazi "PNS Ghazi") sank off the fairway
[buoy](/wiki/Buoy "Buoy") of [Visakhapatnam](/wiki/Visakhapatnam
"Visakhapatnam") near the eastern coast of India, making it the first
submarine casualty in the waters around the [Indian
subcontinent](/wiki/Indian_subcontinent "Indian subcontinent").

Unlike the [1965 war](/wiki/Indo-Pakistani_War_of_1965 "Indo-Pakistani War of
1965"), the [Pakistan Navy](/wiki/Pakistan_Navy "Pakistan Navy") was ill-
prepared for the naval conflict with India and the [Navy
NHQ](/wiki/NHQ_\(Pakistan_Navy\) "NHQ \(Pakistan Navy\)") staffers and
commanders knew very well that the Navy was ill-prepared for the war.[103]:65
The Pakistan Navy was in no condition of fighting an offensive war in deep sea
against the [Indian Navy](/wiki/Indian_Navy "Indian Navy"), and neither was it
in a condition to mount serious defence against Indian Navy's seaborne
encroachment.[104]:75–76

In the western theatre of the war, the Indian Navy's [Western Naval
Command](/wiki/Western_Naval_Command "Western Naval Command") under [Vice
Admiral](/wiki/Vice_admiral "Vice admiral") [S.N.
Kohli](/wiki/Sourendra_Nath_Kohli "Sourendra Nath Kohli"), successfully
launched a surprise attack on [Karachi port](/wiki/Port_of_Karachi "Port of
Karachi") on the night of 4/5 December 1971 under the codename
[_Trident_](/wiki/Operation_Trident_\(Indo-Pakistani_War\) "Operation Trident
\(Indo-Pakistani War\)").[19] The naval attack involving the
[Soviet](/wiki/Soviet_Navy "Soviet Navy")-built [Osa missile boats](/wiki/Osa-
class_missile_boat "Osa-class missile boat") sank the Pakistan Navy's
[destroyer](/wiki/Destroyer "Destroyer") [PNS  _Khyber_](/wiki/PNS_Khyber "PNS
Khyber") and [minesweeper](/wiki/Minesweeper_\(ship\) "Minesweeper \(ship\)")
[PNS  _Muhafiz_](/wiki/PNS_Muhafiz "PNS Muhafiz") while [PNS  _Shah
Jahan_](/wiki/PNS_Shah_Jahan_\(DD-962\) "PNS Shah Jahan \(DD-962\)") was also
badly damaged.[19] In retaliation, the Pakistan Navy submarines,
[_Hangor_](/wiki/PNS_Hangor_\(S131\) "PNS Hangor \(S131\)"), _Mangro_ , and
_Shushuk_ , began their operations to seek out the major Indian
warships.[104]:86–95[105] Pakistani naval sources reported that about 720
Pakistani sailors were killed or wounded, and Pakistan lost reserve fuel and
many commercial ships, thus crippling the Pakistan Navy's further involvement
in the conflict.[104]:85–87 On 9 December 1971, _Hangor_ reportedly sank [INS
_Khukri_](/wiki/INS_Khukri_\(F149\) "INS Khukri \(F149\)"), inflicting 194
Indian casualties, and this attack was the first submarine kill since [World
War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II").[106]:229[107]

The [sinking of INS _Khukri_](/wiki/INS_Khukri_\(F149\)#Incident "INS Khukri
\(F149\)") was followed by another attack on Karachi port on the night of 8/9
December 1971 under the codename [_Python_](/wiki/Operation_Python "Operation
Python").[19] A [squadron](/wiki/Squadron_\(naval\) "Squadron \(naval\)") of
Indian Navy's Osa missile boats approached the [Karachi
port](/wiki/Karachi_port "Karachi port") and launched a series of Soviet-
acquired [Styx missiles](/wiki/P-15_Termit "P-15 Termit"), that resulted in
further destruction of reserve fuel tanks and the sinking of three Pakistani
merchant ships, as well as foreign ships docked in Karachi.[108] The Pakistan
Air Force did not attack the Indian Navy ships, and confusion remained the
next day when the civilian pilots of [Pakistan
International](/wiki/Pakistan_International_Airlines "Pakistan International
Airlines"), acting as [reconnaissance](/wiki/Reconnaissance "Reconnaissance")
war pilots, misidentified [PNS  _Zulfiqar_](/wiki/PNS_Zulfiqar_\(K265\) "PNS
Zulfiqar \(K265\)") and the air force [attacked its own
warship](/wiki/Friendly_fire "Friendly fire"), inflicting major damages and
killing several officers on board.[109]

In the eastern theatre of the war, the Indian [Eastern Naval
Command](/wiki/Eastern_Naval_Command "Eastern Naval Command"), under Vice
Admiral [Nilakanta Krishnan](/wiki/Nilakanta_Krishnan "Nilakanta Krishnan"),
completely isolated East Pakistan by a [naval blockade](/wiki/Naval_blockade
"Naval blockade") in the [Bay of Bengal](/wiki/Bay_of_Bengal "Bay of Bengal"),
trapping the Eastern Pakistan Navy and eight foreign merchant ships in their
ports.[104]:82–83 From 4 December onwards, the aircraft carrier [INS
_Vikrant_](/wiki/INS_Vikrant_\(R11\) "INS Vikrant \(R11\)") was deployed, and
its [Sea Hawk](/wiki/Hawker_Sea_Hawk "Hawker Sea Hawk") fighter-bombers
attacked many coastal towns in East Pakistan, including Chittagong and [Cox's
Bazar](/wiki/Cox%27s_Bazar "Cox's Bazar").[110] Pakistan countered the threat
by sending the submarine [PNS  _Ghazi_](/wiki/PNS_Ghazi "PNS Ghazi"), which
[sank](/wiki/Sinking_of_PNS_Ghazi "Sinking of PNS Ghazi") en route under
mysterious circumstances off [Visakhapatnam](/wiki/Visakhapatnam
"Visakhapatnam")'s coast.[111][112] Due to high number of defections, the Navy
relied on deploying the [Pakistan Marines](/wiki/Pakistan_Marines "Pakistan
Marines") \- led by [Rear Admiral](/wiki/Rear_Admiral "Rear Admiral") [Leslie
Mungavin](/wiki/Leslie_Mungavin "Leslie Mungavin") \- where they had to
conduct [riverine operations](/wiki/Riverine_Warfare "Riverine Warfare")
against the Indian Army, but they too had to suffer major losses, mainly due
to their lack of understanding of [expeditionary
warfare](/wiki/Expeditionary_warfare "Expeditionary warfare") and the [wet
terrain](/wiki/Geography_of_Bangladesh "Geography of Bangladesh") of East
Pakistan.[113]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/INS_Vikrant_%28R11%29_launches_an_Alize_aircraft_during_Indo-
Pakistani_War_of_1971.jpg/220px-
INS_Vikrant_%28R11%29_launches_an_Alize_aircraft_during_Indo-
Pakistani_War_of_1971.jpg)](/wiki/File:INS_Vikrant_\(R11\)_launches_an_Alize_aircraft_during_Indo-
Pakistani_War_of_1971.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:INS_Vikrant_\(R11\)_launches_an_Alize_aircraft_during_Indo-
Pakistani_War_of_1971.jpg "Enlarge")

Indian aircraft carrier [INS  _Vikrant_](/wiki/INS_Vikrant_\(R11\) "INS
Vikrant \(R11\)") launches an [Alize aircraft](/wiki/Breguet_Aliz%C3%A9
"Breguet Alizé")

The damage inflicted on the Pakistan Navy stood at 7 [gunboats](/wiki/Gunboat
"Gunboat"), 1 minesweeper, 1 submarine, 2 destroyers, 3 patrol crafts
belonging to the [coast guard](/wiki/Coast_guard "Coast guard"), 18 cargo,
supply and communication vessels; and large-scale damage inflicted on the
naval base and docks in the coastal town of Karachi. Three merchant navy ships
– _Anwar Baksh_ , _Pasni_ and _Madhumathi_ –[114] and ten smaller vessels were
captured.[115] Around 1900 personnel were lost, while 1413 servicemen were
captured by Indian forces in Dacca.[116] According to one Pakistani scholar,
[Tariq Ali](/wiki/Tariq_Ali "Tariq Ali"), Pakistan lost half its navy in the
war.[117]

### Air operations[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Indo-
Pakistani_War_of_1971&action=edit&section=6 "Edit section: Air operations")]

Main article: [East Pakistan Air Operations,
1971](/wiki/East_Pakistan_Air_Operations,_1971 "East Pakistan Air Operations,
1971")

After the sneak attack, the PAF adopted a defensive stance in response to the
Indian retaliation. As the war progressed, the IAF continued to battle the PAF
over conflict zones but the number of sorties flown by the PAF decreased
day–by–day.[118][119] The IAF flew 4,000 sorties while the PAF offered little
in retaliation, partly because of the paucity of non-Bengali technical
personnel.[19]

This lack of retaliation has also been attributed to the deliberate decision
of the PAF's [Air AHQ](/wiki/AHQ_\(Pakistan_Air_Force\) "AHQ \(Pakistan Air
Force\)") to cut its losses, as it had already incurred huge losses in the
conflict in the liberation war in the East.[120] The PAF avoided making
contacts with the Indian Navy after the latter raided the port of Karachi
twice, but the PAF did retaliate by bombing [Okha](/wiki/Okha,_India "Okha,
India") harbour, destroying the fuel tanks used by the boats that had
attacked.[14][121]

In the East, [No. 14 Squadron Tail
Choppers](/wiki/List_of_Pakistan_Air_Force_squadrons "List of Pakistan Air
Force squadrons") under [Squadron Leader](/wiki/Squadron_Leader "Squadron
Leader") [PQ Mehdi](/wiki/Parvaiz_Mehdi_Qureshi "Parvaiz Mehdi Qureshi"), who
was taken as [POW](/wiki/Prisoner_of_War "Prisoner of War"), was
[destroyed](/wiki/East_Pakistan_operations,_1971 "East Pakistan operations,
1971"), putting the Dhaka air defence out of commission and resulting in
Indian [air superiority](/wiki/Air_superiority "Air superiority") in the
East.[19]

At the end of the war, PAF pilots made successful daring escapes from East
Pakistan to neighboring [Burma](/wiki/Myanmar "Myanmar"); many PAF personnel
had already left the East for Burma on their own luck before Dacca was overrun
by the Indian military in December 1971.[122][_[dead
link](/wiki/Wikipedia:Link_rot "Wikipedia:Link rot")_]

### Indian attacks on Pakistan[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Indo-
Pakistani_War_of_1971&action=edit&section=7 "Edit section: Indian attacks on
Pakistan")]

As Indian Army tightened its grip in the East Pakistan, the Indian Air Force
continued with its pressing attacks against Pakistan as the campaign developed
into a series of daylight anti-airfield, anti-radar, and close-support attacks
by fighter jets, with night attacks against airfields and strategic targets by
[B-57s](/wiki/Martin_B-57_Canberra "Martin B-57 Canberra") and
[C-130](/wiki/Lockheed_C-130_Hercules "Lockheed C-130 Hercules") of Pakistan
and [Canberras](/wiki/English_Electric_Canberra "English Electric Canberra")
and [An-12s](/wiki/Antonov_An-12 "Antonov An-12") of India.[123]:107–108

The PAF deployed the [F-6s](/wiki/Shenyang_J-6 "Shenyang J-6") mainly on
defensive [combat air patrol](/wiki/Combat_air_patrol "Combat air patrol")
missions over their own bases, but without the preferential [air
superiority](/wiki/Air_superiority "Air superiority"), the PAF was unable to
conduct effective offensive operations and its attacks were largely
ineffective.[123]:107–108 The IAF's raids damaged one
[USAF](/wiki/United_States_Air_Force "United States Air Force") and one
[UN](/wiki/United_Nations "United Nations") aircraft in Dacca, while the
[RCAF](/wiki/Royal_Canadian_Air_Force "Royal Canadian Air Force")'s [DHC-4
Caribou](/wiki/De_Havilland_Canada_DHC-4_Caribou "De Havilland Canada DHC-4
Caribou") was also destroyed in [Islamabad](/wiki/Islamabad "Islamabad"),
along with the USAF's [Beech U-8](/wiki/Beechcraft_L-23_Seminole "Beechcraft
L-23 Seminole") owned by the [US military](/wiki/United_States_military
"United States military")'s liaison chief [Brigadier-General](/wiki/Brigadier-
General "Brigadier-General") [Chuck Yeager](/wiki/Chuck_Yeager "Chuck
Yeager").[123]:107[124] Sporadic raids by the IAF continued against PAF
forward air bases in Pakistan until the end of the war, and interdiction and
close-support operations were maintained.[123]:107

One of the most successful air raids by India into West Pakistan happened on 8
December 1971, when Indian Hunter aircraft from
[Pathankot](/wiki/Pathankot_Air_Force_Station "Pathankot Air Force
Station")-based 20 Squadron, attacked the Pakistani base in
[Murid](/wiki/PAF_Base_Murid "PAF Base Murid") and destroyed 5 F-86 aircraft
on the ground. This was confirmed by Pakistan's military historian, Air
Commodore [M Kaiser Tufail](/wiki/Kaiser_Tufail "Kaiser Tufail"), in his book
'In The Ring and On Its Feet - Pakistan Air Force in the 1971 Indo-Pak
War'.[125]

The PAF played a more limited part in the operations and were reinforced by
[F-104s](/wiki/F-104 "F-104") from [Jordan](/wiki/Jordan "Jordan"),
[Mirages](/wiki/Mirage_III "Mirage III") from an unidentified [Middle
Eastern](/wiki/Middle_East "Middle East") ally (remains unknown) and by F-86s
from [Saudi Arabia](/wiki/Saudi_Arabia "Saudi Arabia").[123]:107 Their arrival
helped camouflage the extent of PAF losses, and the [Libyan](/wiki/Libya
"Libya") [F-5s](/wiki/Northrop_F-5 "Northrop F-5") were reportedly deployed to
[Sargodha AFB](/wiki/Sargodha_Airbase "Sargodha Airbase"), perhaps as a
potential training unit to prepare Pakistani pilots for an influx of more F-5s
from Saudi Arabia.[123]:112 The IAF was able to conduct a wide range of
missions – troop support; air combat; deep penetration strikes; para-dropping
behind enemy lines; feints to draw enemy fighters away from the actual target;
bombing and reconnaissance.[123]:107 The PAF, which was solely focused on air
combat, was blown out of the subcontinent’s skies within the first week of the
war.[123]:107 Those PAF aircraft that survived took refuge at
[Iranian](/wiki/Iran "Iran") air bases or in concrete bunkers, refusing to
offer a fight.[126]

India flew 1,978 sorties in the East and about 4,000 in Pakistan, while the
PAF flew about 30 and 2,840 at the respective fronts.[123]:107 More than 80
percent of IAF sorties were close-support and interdiction and about 45 IAF
aircraft were lost.[8]

Pakistan lost 75 aircraft,[8] not including any F-6s, Mirage IIIs, or the six
Jordanian F-104s which failed to return to their donors.[8] The imbalance in
air losses was explained by the IAF's considerably higher sortie rate and its
emphasis on ground-attack missions.[8]

### Ground operations[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Indo-
Pakistani_War_of_1971&action=edit&section=8 "Edit section: Ground
operations")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/1/11/T-55_tanks_in_the_Bangladesh_Liberation_War.jpg/220px-T-55_tanks_in_the_Bangladesh_Liberation_War.jpg)](/wiki/File:T-55_tanks_in_the_Bangladesh_Liberation_War.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:T-55_tanks_in_the_Bangladesh_Liberation_War.jpg "Enlarge")

Indian T-55 tanks on their way to Dhaka.

Before the start of the war, the Indian Army was extremely well organized on
both fronts and had enjoyed significant numerical superiority over the
Pakistan Army.[127]:596 The Indian Army's extraordinary war performance at
both fronts brought up the prestige, confidence, and dignity that it had lost
during the [war with China](/wiki/1962_Sino-Indian_conflict "1962 Sino-Indian
conflict") in 1962.[128]

When the conflict started, the war immediately took a decisive turn in favour
of India and their [Bengali rebel allies](/wiki/Mukti_Bahini "Mukti Bahini")
militarily and diplomatically.[127]:596 On both fronts, Pakistan launched
several ground offensives, but the Indian Army held its ground and initiated
well-coordinated ground operations on both fronts.[127]:596 Major ground
attacks were concentrated on the western border by the Pakistan Army, together
with the Pakistan Marines in the south border, but the Indian Army was
successful in penetrating into Pakistani soil. It eventually made some quick
and initial gains, including the capture of around 5,795 square miles (15,010
km2)[5][6] of Pakistani territory; this land gained by India in [Azad
Kashmir](/wiki/Azad_Kashmir "Azad Kashmir"), [Punjab](/wiki/Punjab,_Pakistan
"Punjab, Pakistan") and [Sindh](/wiki/Sindh "Sindh") sectors was later ceded
in the [Simla Agreement](/wiki/Simla_Agreement "Simla Agreement") of 1972, as
a gesture of goodwill.[7] Casualties inflicted to Pakistan Army's [I
Corps](/wiki/I_Corps_\(Pakistan\) "I Corps \(Pakistan\)") and [II
Corps](/wiki/II_Corps_\(Pakistan\) "II Corps \(Pakistan\)") were very high,
and many soldiers perished due to lack of operational planning and lack of
coordination within the army's formations against Indian Army's
[Southern](/wiki/Southern_Command_\(India\) "Southern Command \(India\)") and
[Western Commands](/wiki/Western_Command_\(India\) "Western Command
\(India\)").[129]:82–93 By the time the war came to end, Pakistan army
soldiers and marines were highly demoralized - both emotionally and
psychologically - on the western front and had no
[will](/wiki/Will_\(philosophy\) "Will \(philosophy\)") to put up a defensive
fight against the approaching Indian Army soldiers.[130]:1–2[131]:26–27

The War Enquiry Commission later exposed the fact that for the Pakistan Army,
the arms and training of soldiers and officers were needed at every level, and
every level of command.[132]

On 23 November 1971, the Indian Army conventionally penetrated to the eastern
fronts and crossed East Pakistan's borders to join their [Bengali
nationalist](/wiki/Mitro_Bahini "Mitro Bahini") allies.[133]:156 Contrary to
the [1965 war](/wiki/Indo-Pakistani_war_of_1965 "Indo-Pakistani war of 1965"),
which had emphasised set-piece battles and slow advances, this time the
strategy adopted was a swift, three-pronged assault of nine infantry divisions
with attached armoured units and close air support that rapidly converged on
Dacca, the capital of East Pakistan.[133]:156 [Lieutenant
General](/wiki/Lieutenant_General "Lieutenant General") [Jagjit Singh
Aurora](/wiki/Jagjit_Singh_Aurora "Jagjit Singh Aurora"), the [GOC-
in-C](/wiki/General_Officer_Commanding-in-Chief "General Officer Commanding-
in-Chief") of the India Army's [Eastern
Command](/wiki/Eastern_Command_\(India\) "Eastern Command \(India\)"), led the
Indian full thrust into East Pakistan. As the Indian Eastern Command attacked
the [Pakistan Eastern Command](/wiki/Pakistan_Eastern_Command "Pakistan
Eastern Command"), the Indian Air Force rapidly destroyed the small air
contingent in East Pakistan and put the Dacca airfield out of
commission.[133]:156 In the meantime, the Indian Navy effectively blockaded
East Pakistan.[133]:156

The Indian campaign employed "_[blitzkrieg](/wiki/Blitzkrieg "Blitzkrieg")_ "
techniques, exploiting weaknesses in the enemy's positions and bypassing
opposition, and this resulted in a swift victory.[134]:802 Faced with
insurmountable losses, the Pakistani military capitulated in less than a
fortnight and psychological panic spread in the Eastern Command's military
leadership.[134]:802 Subsequently, the Indian Army encircled Dacca and issued
an ultimatum to surrender in "30-minutes" time window on 16 December
1971.[135] Upon hearing the ultimatum, the Pakistan Eastern Command, led by
its commander Lieutenant-General [A.A.K. Niazi](/wiki/Amir_Abdullah_Khan_Niazi
"Amir Abdullah Khan Niazi"), surrendered without putting up a fight or
offering any resistance.[133] On 16 December 1971, Pakistan ultimately called
for unilateral ceasefire and surrendered its [combined
military](/wiki/Pakistani_military "Pakistani military") to the Indian Army–
hence ending the Indo-Pakistani war of 1971.[133]

On the ground, Pakistan suffered the most with 8,000 killed and 25,000
wounded, while India only had 3,000 dead and 12,000 wounded.[18] The loss of
[armoured vehicles](/wiki/Vehicle_armour "Vehicle armour") was similarly
imbalanced and this finally represented a major defeat for Pakistan.[18]

### Surrender of Pakistan Eastern Command in East
Pakistan[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Indo-
Pakistani_War_of_1971&action=edit&section=9 "Edit section: Surrender of
Pakistan Eastern Command in East Pakistan")]

Main articles: [Instrument of Surrender
(1971)](/wiki/Instrument_of_Surrender_\(1971\) "Instrument of Surrender
\(1971\)") and [East Pakistan Military
Command](/wiki/East_Pakistan_Military_Command "East Pakistan Military
Command")

Officially, the Instrument of Surrender of Pakistan Eastern Command stationed
in East Pakistan, was signed between the Lieutenant General Jagjit Singh
Aurora, the GOC-in-C of Indian Eastern Command and Lieutenant-General A.A.K.
Niazi, the Commander of the Pakistan Eastern Command, at the [Ramna Race
Course](/wiki/Ramna_Race_Course "Ramna Race Course") in Dacca at 16:31Hrs
[IST](/wiki/Indian_Standard_Time "Indian Standard Time") on 16 December
1971.[136]:156–157 As the [surrender](/wiki/Surrender_\(military\) "Surrender
\(military\)") was accepted by Lieutenant-General Aurora without a word, the
surrounding crowds on the race course started shouting [anti-
Pakistan](/wiki/Anti-Pakistan_sentiment "Anti-Pakistan sentiment") slogans,
and there were reports of abuses aimed at the surrendering commanders of
Pakistani military.[136]:157[137][_[self-published
source](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability#Self-published_sources
"Wikipedia:Verifiability")_]

Hostilities officially ended at 14:30 [GMT](/wiki/Greenwich_Mean_Time
"Greenwich Mean Time") on 17 December, after the [fall of
Dacca](/wiki/Fall_of_Dhaka "Fall of Dhaka") on 15 December, and India claimed
large gains of territory in Pakistan (although pre-war boundaries were
recognised after the war), and the independence of Pakistan's East Wing as
Bangladesh was confirmed.[123]:107

Following the surrender, the Indian Army took approximately 90,000 Pakistani
servicemen and their Bengali supporters as [POWs](/wiki/Prisoners_of_war
"Prisoners of war"), making it the largest surrender since [World War
II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II").[136]:157 Initial counts recorded that
approximately 79,676 war prisoners were uniformed personnel, and the
overwhelming majority of the war prisoners were officers - most of them were
in the Army and Navy, while relatively small numbers were from the Air Force
and Marines; others in larger number were serving in the
[paramilitary](/wiki/Paramilitary_forces_of_Pakistan "Paramilitary forces of
Pakistan").[138]

The remaining prisoners were civilians who were either family members of the
military personnel or collaborators ([razakars](/wiki/Razakars_\(Pakistan\)
"Razakars \(Pakistan\)")). The [Hamoodur Rahman
Commission](/wiki/Hamoodur_Rahman_Commission "Hamoodur Rahman Commission") and
the [POW Investigation Commission](/wiki/Indo-
Pakistani_War_of_1971_Prisoners_of_War_Investigation "Indo-Pakistani War of
1971 Prisoners of War Investigation") reports instituted by Pakistan lists the
Pakistani POWs as given in the table below. Apart from soldiers, it was
estimated that 15,000 Bengali civilians were also made prisoners of war.[139]

Inter-Service Branch | Number of captured Pakistani POWs | Officer Commanding  
---|---|---

![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Air_Force_Ensign_of_Pakistan.svg/23px-Air_Force_Ensign_of_Pakistan.svg.png) [Pakistan Air Force](/wiki/Pakistan_Air_Force "Pakistan Air Force") | 833 | [Air Commodore](/wiki/Air_Commodore "Air Commodore") [Inamul Haq](/wiki/Inamul_Haque_Khan "Inamul Haque Khan")
