## Foreign reaction and involvement[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Indo-
Pakistani_War_of_1971&action=edit&section=10 "Edit section: Foreign reaction
and involvement")]

### United States and Soviet Union[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Indo-
Pakistani_War_of_1971&action=edit&section=11 "Edit section: United States and
Soviet Union")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Blood_telegram.png/220px-
Blood_telegram.png)](/wiki/File:Blood_telegram.png)

[](/wiki/File:Blood_telegram.png "Enlarge")

The [Blood Telegram](/wiki/Blood_Telegram "Blood Telegram")

The [Soviet Union](/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet Union") sympathised with the
[East Pakistanis](/wiki/East_Pakistanis "East Pakistanis"), and supported the
Indian Army and [Mukti Bahini](/wiki/Mukti_Bahini "Mukti Bahini")'s incursion
against Pakistan during the war, in a broader view of recognising that the
[succession](/wiki/Independence_of_Bangladesh "Independence of Bangladesh") of
East Pakistan as [Independent
Bangladesh](/wiki/People%27s_Republic_of_Bangladesh "People's Republic of
Bangladesh") would weaken the position of its rivals— the [United States and
China](/wiki/United_states_and_china "United states and china"). The Soviet
Union gave assurances to India that if a confrontation with the United States
or China developed, it would take counter-measures. This assurance was
enshrined in the [Indo-Soviet Treaty of Friendship and
Cooperation](/wiki/Indo-Soviet_Treaty_of_Friendship_and_Cooperation "Indo-
Soviet Treaty of Friendship and Cooperation") signed in August 1971.[140]

However, the Indo-Soviet treaty did not mean a total commitment to every
Indian position, even though the Soviet Union had accepted the Indian position
during the conflict, according to author Robert Jackson.[141]:72–73 The Soviet
Union continued its sympathetic gesture to Pakistan until mid-October 1971,
when it stressed Pakistan to come up with a political settlement and affirmed
its continuation of industrial aid to Pakistan.[141]:73 By November 1971, the
[Soviet ambassador](/wiki/Ambassador_of_the_Soviet_Union_to_Pakistan
"Ambassador of the Soviet Union to Pakistan") to Pakistan [Alexei
Rodionov](/wiki/Aleksei_A._Rodionov "Aleksei A. Rodionov") directed a
secretive message (_[Rodionov message](/wiki/Rodionov_message "Rodionov
message")_) that ultimately warned Pakistan that "it will be embarking on a
suicidal course if it escalates tensions in the subcontinent.[91]:part-3

The [United States](/wiki/United_States "United States") stood with Pakistan
by supporting it morally, politically, economically, and materially when [U.S.
President](/wiki/President_of_the_United_States "President of the United
States") [Richard Nixon](/wiki/Richard_Nixon "Richard Nixon") and his
[Secretary of State](/wiki/United_States_Secretary_of_State "United States
Secretary of State") [Henry Kissinger](/wiki/Henry_Kissinger "Henry
Kissinger") refused to use rhetoric in a hopeless attempt to intervene in a
large [civil war](/wiki/Civil_war "Civil war"). The U.S. establishment
perceived to the impression that they needed Pakistan to help stop Soviet
[influence](/wiki/Great_Game "Great Game") in [South Asia](/wiki/South_Asia
"South Asia") in an informal alliance with India.[142]:281 During the [Cold
War](/wiki/Cold_War_\(1953%E2%80%9362\) "Cold War \(1953–62\)"), Pakistan was
a close [formal ally](/wiki/CENTO "CENTO") of the United States and also had
[close relations](/wiki/China%E2%80%93Pakistan_relations "China–Pakistan
relations") with the [People's Republic of
China](/wiki/People%27s_Republic_of_China "People's Republic of China"), with
whom Nixon had been negotiating a [_rapprochement_](/wiki/Sino-
American_relations#Rapprochement "Sino-American relations") and where he
[intended to visit](/wiki/Nixon_visit_to_China "Nixon visit to China") in
February 1972.[143] Nixon feared that an Indian invasion of
[Pakistan](/wiki/Pakistan "Pakistan") would mean total Soviet domination of
the region, and that it would seriously undermine the [global
position](/wiki/Balance_of_power_\(international_relations\) "Balance of power
\(international relations\)") of the United States and the regional position
of America's new tactical ally, China.[142]:281–282 Nixon encouraged
[Jordan](/wiki/Jordan "Jordan") and [Iran](/wiki/Iran "Iran") to send military
supplies to Pakistan, while also encouraging China to increase its arms
supplies to Pakistan, but all supplies were very limited.[144]:61[145] The
Nixon administration also ignored reports it received of the "genocidal"
activities of the Pakistani military in East Pakistan, most notably the [Blood
telegram](/wiki/Blood_telegram "Blood telegram"), and this prompted widespread
criticism and condemnation - both by the [United States
Congress](/wiki/United_States_Congress "United States Congress") and in the
international press.[62][146][147]

Then [U.S. Ambassador to the United
Nations](/wiki/United_States_Ambassador_to_the_United_Nations "United States
Ambassador to the United Nations"), [George Bush, Sr](/wiki/George_H.W._Bush
"George H.W. Bush"), introduced a resolution in the [UN Security
Council](/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council "United Nations Security
Council") calling for a cease-fire and the withdrawal of armed forces by India
and Pakistan.[141]:73 However, it was
[vetoed](/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council_veto_power "United Nations
Security Council veto power") by the Soviet Union, and the following days
witnessed the use of great pressure on the Soviets from the Nixon-Kissinger
duo to get India to withdraw, but to no avail.[148]

When Pakistan's defeat in the eastern sector seemed certain, Nixon deployed
[Task Force 74](/wiki/Task_Force_74 "Task Force 74") led by the [aircraft
carrier](/wiki/Aircraft_carrier "Aircraft carrier") [USS
_Enterprise_](/wiki/USS_Enterprise_\(CVN-65\) "USS Enterprise \(CVN-65\)")
into the [Bay of Bengal](/wiki/Bay_of_Bengal "Bay of Bengal"). _Enterprise_
and its escort ships arrived on station on 11 December 1971.[149]:xxxx
According to a Russian documentary, the [United Kingdom](/wiki/United_Kingdom
"United Kingdom") deployed a carrier battle group led by the aircraft carrier
[HMS  _Eagle_](/wiki/HMS_Eagle_\(R05\) "HMS Eagle \(R05\)") to the
Bay,[140][150][_[better source needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:NOTRS
"Wikipedia:NOTRS")_] on her final deployment.

On 6 and 13 December, the [Soviet Navy](/wiki/Soviet_Navy "Soviet Navy")
dispatched two groups of [cruisers](/wiki/Cruiser "Cruiser") and
[destroyers](/wiki/Destroyer "Destroyer") from [Vladivostok](/wiki/Vladivostok
"Vladivostok");[140] they trailed US Task Force 74 into the Indian Ocean from
18 December 1971 until 7 January 1972. The Soviets also had a [nuclear
submarine](/wiki/Ballistic_missile_submarine "Ballistic missile submarine") to
help ward off the threat posed by the USS _Enterprise_ task force in the
Indian Ocean.[151][152]

As the war progressed, it became apparent to the United States that India was
going to invade and disintegrate Pakistan in a matter of weeks, therefore
President Nixon spoke with the [USSR Secretary
General](/wiki/General_Secretary_of_the_Communist_Party_of_the_Soviet_Union
"General Secretary of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union") [Leonid
Brezhnev](/wiki/Leonid_Brezhnev "Leonid Brezhnev") on a
[hotline](/wiki/Moscow%E2%80%93Washington_hotline "Moscow–Washington hotline")
on 10 December, where Nixon reportedly urged Brezhnev to restrain India as he
quoted: "in the strongest possible terms to restrain India with which … you
[Brezhnev] have great influence and for whose actions you must share
responsibility."[153]

After the war, the United States accepted the new balance of power and
realised India to be a dominant player in South Asia; the US immediately
engaged in strengthening [bilateral relations between the two
countries](/wiki/Indo-US_Relations "Indo-US Relations") in the successive
years.[154]:69 The Soviet Union, while being sympathetic to Pakistan's loss,
decided to engage with Pakistan after sending an invitation through Rodionov
to [Z A Bhutto](/wiki/Zulfikar_Ali_Bhutto "Zulfikar Ali Bhutto"), who [paid a
state visit](/wiki/1972_Bhutto_visit_to_Soviet_Union "1972 Bhutto visit to
Soviet Union") to the Soviet Union in 1972 to strengthen [bilateral
relations](/wiki/Pakistan-Soviet_Union_relations "Pakistan-Soviet Union
relations") that continued over the years.[155]:16

### China and Iran[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Indo-
Pakistani_War_of_1971&action=edit&section=12 "Edit section: China and Iran")]

During the course of the war, [China](/wiki/China "China") harshly criticised
India for its involvement in the East Pakistan crises, and accused India of
having, [imperialistic](/wiki/Indian_Century "Indian Century") designs in
South Asia.[156]:19 Before the war started, Chinese leaders and officials had
long been philosophically advising the [Pakistan
government](/wiki/Pakistan_Government "Pakistan Government") to make peaceful
political settlements with the East Pakistani leaders, as China feared that
India was secretly supporting, infiltrating, and arming the Bengali rebels
against the [East Pakistani government](/wiki/Government_of_East_Pakistan
"Government of East Pakistan").[157]:61[158]:285 China was also critical of
the [Government of East Pakistan](/wiki/Government_of_East_Pakistan
"Government of East Pakistan"), led by its
[Governor](/wiki/Governor_of_East_Pakistan "Governor of East Pakistan")
Lieutenant-General Tikka Khan - which used ruthless measures to deal with the
Bengali opposition - and did not endorse the Pakistani position on that
issue.[158]:285 When the war started, China reproached India for its direct
involvement and infiltration in East Pakistan.[158]:285 China disagreed with
Pakistani President Yahya Khan's consideration of military options, and
criticised [East Pakistan Awami League](/wiki/East_Pakistan_Awami_League "East
Pakistan Awami League") politicians' ties with India.[158]:285

When the war started, China reacted with great alarm when the prospects of
Indian invasion of Pakistan and integration of [Pakistan-administered
Kashmir](/wiki/Pakistan-administered_Kashmir "Pakistan-administered Kashmir")
into their [side of Kashmir](/wiki/Indian-controlled_Kashmir "Indian-
controlled Kashmir"), became imminent.[100] US President Nixon encouraged
China to mobilise its [armed forces](/wiki/Peoples_Liberation_Army "Peoples
Liberation Army") along its border with India to discourage the Indian
assault, but the Chinese did not respond to this encouragement since the
Indian Army's [Northern Command](/wiki/Northern_Command_\(India\) "Northern
Command \(India\)") was well prepared to guard the [Line of Actual
Control](/wiki/Line_of_Actual_Control "Line of Actual Control"), and was
already engaging and making advances against the Pakistan Army's [X
Corps](/wiki/X_Corps_\(Pakistan\) "X Corps \(Pakistan\)") in the [Line of
Control](/wiki/Line_of_Control "Line of Control").[159]:xxxiii

China did not welcome the break-up of Pakistan's unity by the East Pakistani
politicians, and effectively vetoed the membership of
[Bangladesh](/wiki/Bangladesh "Bangladesh") when it applied to the [United
Nations](/wiki/United_Nations "United Nations") in 1972.[160] China objected
to admitting Bangladesh on the grounds that two [UN
resolutions](/wiki/Un_resolutions "Un resolutions") concerning Bangladesh,
requiring the [repatriation](/wiki/Delhi_Agreement "Delhi Agreement") of
Pakistani [POWs and civilians](/wiki/Indo-
Pakistani_War_of_1971_Prisoners_of_War_Investigation "Indo-Pakistani War of
1971 Prisoners of War Investigation"), had not yet been implemented.[161]
Furthermore, China was also among the last countries to
[recognise](/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Bangladesh "Foreign relations of
Bangladesh") the independence of [Bangladesh](/wiki/Bangladesh "Bangladesh"),
refusing to do so until 31 August 1975.[162][160]:226–227[163] To this date,
China's relations with Bangladesh are determined by the Pakistan
factor.[164]:69

During the course of the conflict, [Iran](/wiki/Iran "Iran") also stood with
Pakistan politically and diplomatically.[165]:78–79 It was concerned with the
imminent break-up of Pakistan which, it feared, would have caused the state to
fractionalize into [small pieces](/wiki/Balkanization "Balkanization"),
ultimately resulting in Iran's encirclement by rivals. After the war, however,
Iran began cementing [ties with India](/wiki/India%E2%80%93Iran_relations
"India–Iran relations") based on mutual security co-
operation.[165]:79[_[verification needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability
"Wikipedia:Verifiability")_] At the beginning of the conflict, Iran had helped
Pakistan by sheltering PAF's fighter jets and providing it with free fuel to
take part in the conflict, in an attempt to keep Pakistan's regional integrity
united.[165]:80[_[verification needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability
"Wikipedia:Verifiability")_] When Pakistan called for unilateral ceasefire and
the surrender was announced, the [Shah of Iran](/wiki/Mohammad_Reza_Pahlavi
"Mohammad Reza Pahlavi") hastily responded by preparing the [Iranian
military](/wiki/Iranian_military "Iranian military") to come up with
contingency plans to forcefully invade Pakistan and annex its [Balochistan
province](/wiki/Balochistan,_Pakistan "Balochistan, Pakistan") into [its side
of Balochistan](/wiki/Balochistan,_Iran "Balochistan, Iran"), by any means
necessary, before anybody else did it.[165]:79[_[verification
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability "Wikipedia:Verifiability")_]

## Aftermath[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Indo-
Pakistani_War_of_1971&action=edit&section=13 "Edit section: Aftermath")]

### India[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Indo-
Pakistani_War_of_1971&action=edit&section=14 "Edit section: India")]

The war stripped Pakistan of more than half of its population, and with nearly
one-third of its army in captivity, clearly established India's military and
political dominance of the subcontinent.[24] India successfully led a
diplomatic campaign to isolate Pakistan and skillfully manipulate Pakistan's
supporting countries to limit the extent of support to Pakistan.[127]:596 In
addition, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's state visit to [United
Kingdom](/wiki/United_Kingdom "United Kingdom") and [France](/wiki/France
"France") further helped break ice with the United States, and blocked any
pro-Pakistan resolution in the [United Nations](/wiki/United_Nations "United
Nations").[127]:596 There was also a meeting between Prime Minister Gandhi and
President Nixon in November 1971,[_[clarification
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify "Wikipedia:Please clarify")_] where she
rejected the US advice against intervening in the conflict.[127]:596

The victory also defined India's much broader role in foreign politics, as
many countries in the world had come to realise - including the United States
- that the [balance of
power](/wiki/Balance_of_power_\(international_relations\) "Balance of power
\(international relations\)") had shifted to India as a major player in the
region.[165]:80[166]:57 In the wake of changing geopolitical realities, India
sought to establish closer relations with regional countries such as Iran,
which was a traditional ally of Pakistan.[166]:57 The United States itself
accepted a new balance of power, and when India conducted a [surprise nuclear
test](/wiki/Smiling_Buddha "Smiling Buddha") in 1974, the US notified India
that it had no "interest in actions designed to achieve new balance of
power."[154]:69

In spite of the magnitude of the victory, India was surprisingly restrained in
its reaction.[24] Mostly, Indian leaders seemed pleased by the relative ease
with which they had accomplished their goals—the establishment of Bangladesh
and the prospect of an early return to their homeland of the 10 million
Bengali refugees who were the cause of the war.[24] In announcing the
Pakistani surrender, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi declared in the Indian
Parliament:

> Dacca is now the free capital of a free country. We hail the people of
> Bangladesh in their hour of triumph. All nations who value the human spirit
> will recognize it as a significant milestone in man's quest for liberty.[24]

Colonel John Gill of [National Defense
University](/wiki/National_Defense_University "National Defense University"),
US, remarks that, while India achieved a military victory, it was not able to
reap the political fruits it might have hoped for in Bangladesh. After a brief
'honeymoon' phase between India and Bangladesh, [their
relationship](/wiki/Bangladesh%E2%80%93India_relations "Bangladesh–India
relations") began to sour. India's relations with Bangladesh have remained
frequently problematic and tense.[167][168] Whilst India enjoys excellent
relations with Bangladesh during [Awami League](/wiki/Awami_League "Awami
League") tenures, relations deteriorate when the
[BNP](/wiki/Bangladesh_Nationalist_Party "Bangladesh Nationalist Party") is in
power in Bangladesh. A 2014 [Pew Research Center](/wiki/Pew_Research_Center
"Pew Research Center") opinion poll in Bangladesh found that India was
perceived as the greatest threat to Bangladesh. This was the top choice (27%)
of Bangladeshis. However, 70% of Bangladeshis held a positive view of India:
while 50% of Bangladeshis held a positive view of Pakistan.[169]

### Pakistan[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Indo-
Pakistani_War_of_1971&action=edit&section=15 "Edit section: Pakistan")]

For Pakistan it was a complete and humiliating defeat,[24] a psychological
setback that came from a defeat at the hands of rival India.[31] Pakistan lost
half its population and a significant portion of its economy, and suffered
setbacks to its geopolitical role in South Asia.[24][31] In the post-war era,
Pakistan struggled to absorb the lessons learned from the military
interventions in the democratic system and the impact of the Pakistani
military's failure was grave and long-lasting.[170][171]

From the [geopolitical](/wiki/Geopolitics "Geopolitics") [point of
view](/wiki/Point_of_view_\(philosophy\) "Point of view \(philosophy\)"), the
war ended in the [breaking-up of the
unity](/wiki/Breakup_of_East_and_West_Pakistan "Breakup of East and West
Pakistan") of Pakistan from being the largest [Muslim
country](/wiki/Muslim_world "Muslim world") in the world to its [politico-
economic](/wiki/Stagflation_in_Pakistan "Stagflation in Pakistan") and
[military collapse](/wiki/Instrument_of_Surrender_\(1971\) "Instrument of
Surrender \(1971\)") that resulted from a direct [foreign
intervention](/wiki/India_and_state-sponsored_terrorism "India and state-
sponsored terrorism") in 1971.[172]:50[173][_[self-published
source](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability#Self-published_sources
"Wikipedia:Verifiability")_]:47[174]:1[175][176] The Pakistani policy-making
institutions further feared that the historicity of the [Two-nation
theory](/wiki/Two-nation_theory "Two-nation theory") was disproved by the war,
that [Muslim nationalism](/wiki/Muslim_nationalism_in_South_Asia "Muslim
nationalism in South Asia") had proved insufficient to keep Bengalis part of
Pakistan.[31] The [Pakistani government](/wiki/Pakistani_government "Pakistani
government") had to engage an [investigation commission](/wiki/Indo-
Pakistani_War_of_1971_Prisoners_of_War_Investigation "Indo-Pakistani War of
1971 Prisoners of War Investigation") when the [Pakistani
military](/wiki/Pakistani_military "Pakistani military") suffered further
humiliation: Their approximately 90,000 prisoners of war were to be released
by India only after the negotiation and signing of the
[agreement](/wiki/Simla_Agreement "Simla Agreement") that was signed in
[Simla](/wiki/Simla "Simla") on 2 July 1972. In addition to repatriation of
prisoners of war and [transfer of
population](/wiki/Transfer_of_Population_Under_the_Terms_of_Delhi_Agreement
"Transfer of Population Under the Terms of Delhi Agreement"), the agreement
established an ongoing structure for the negotiated resolution of future
conflicts between India and Pakistan. In signing the agreement, Pakistan also,
by implication, had to recognise the former East Pakistan as the now
independent and [sovereign state](/wiki/Sovereign_state "Sovereign state") of
Bangladesh.

The [Pakistani people](/wiki/Pakistani_society "Pakistani society") were not
mentally prepared to accept the magnitude of this kind of defeat, as the
[state electronic media](/wiki/Pakistan_Television_Corporation "Pakistan
Television Corporation") had been projecting imaginary victories; however, the
[privately-owned electronic news media](/wiki/News_channels_in_Pakistan "News
channels in Pakistan") coverage in East Pakistan had reported the complexity
of the situation.[31] When the ceasefire that came from the
[surrender](/wiki/Instrument_of_Surrender_\(1971\) "Instrument of Surrender
\(1971\)") of East Pakistan was finally announced, the people could not come
to terms with the magnitude of defeat; spontaneous demonstrations and massive
protests erupted on the streets of major [metropolitan
cities](/wiki/Cities_in_Pakistan "Cities in Pakistan") in Pakistan. According
to Pakistani historians, the trauma was extremely severe, and the cost of the
war for Pakistan in monetary terms and in human resources was very
high.[177]:xxx[178] Demoralized and finding unable to control the situation,
the Yahya administration fell when President Yahya Khan [turned
over](/wiki/Turnover_\(employment\) "Turnover \(employment\)") his presidency
to [Zulfiqar Ali Bhutto](/wiki/Zulfiqar_Ali_Bhutto "Zulfiqar Ali Bhutto"), who
was sworn in on 20 December 1971 as [President](/wiki/President_of_Pakistan
"President of Pakistan") [with the control of the
military](/wiki/Chief_Martial_Law_Administrator "Chief Martial Law
Administrator").[179]

The loss of East Pakistan shattered the prestige of the Pakistani
military.[31] Pakistan lost half its navy, a quarter of its air force, and a
third of its army.[117] The war also exposed the shortcomings of Pakistan's
declared strategic doctrine that the "defence of East Pakistan lay in West
Pakistan".[180] [Hussain Haqqani](/wiki/Hussain_Haqqani "Hussain Haqqani"), in
his book _Pakistan: Between Mosque and Military_ notes,

> Moreover, the army had failed to fulfill its promises of fighting to the
> last man. The eastern command had laid down arms after losing only 1,300 men
> in battle. In West Pakistan 1,200 military deaths had accompanied lackluster
> military performance.[181]

In his book _The 1971 Indo-Pak War: A Soldier’s Narrative_ , Pakistan Army's
[Major General](/wiki/Major_general "Major general") Hakeem Arshad Qureshi, a
veteran of this conflict, noted:

> We must accept the fact that, as a people, we had also contributed to the
> bifurcation of our own country. It was not a Niazi, or a Yahya, even a
> Mujib, or a Bhutto, or their key assistants, who alone were the cause of our
> break-up, but a corrupted system and a flawed social order that our own
> apathy had allowed to remain in place for years. At the most critical moment
> in our history we failed to check the limitless ambitions of individuals
> with dubious antecedents and to thwart their selfish and irresponsible
> behaviour. It was our collective 'conduct' that had provided the enemy an
> opportunity to dismember us.[182]

The Indian Army Chief in 1971, Field Marshal Sam Manekshaw had the highest
respect for the fighting capability of the Pakistan Army, and he did not
accept the theory that they did not fight the war with enough vigour and
zeal.[183] In a BBC interview, he said:

> The Pakistan Army in East Pakistan fought very gallantly. But they had no
> chance. They were a thousand miles away from their base. I had eight or nine
> months to make my preparations. I had got a superiority of almost 15 to
> 1....[184][185]

[186]

However, independent defence sources stated that the Indian superiority was
less than 2 to 1.[187] The United States Air Force's Brigadier-General Chuck
Yeager, the [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II") veteran and US
flying ace who witnessed the war in 1971, is of the view that Pakistan did not
lose the war, as India did not annex it.[188]

Major reforms were carried out by successive governments in Pakistan after the
war in the light of many insightful recommendations made in the Hamoodur
Rahman Commission's [Report](/wiki/Hamoodur_Rahman_Commission_Report "Hamoodur
Rahman Commission Report").[189]:254 To address the economic disparity, the
[NFC system](/wiki/National_Finance_Commission_Award "National Finance
Commission Award") was established to equally distribute the taxation revenue
among the [four provinces](/wiki/Four_Provinces_\(Pakistan\) "Four Provinces
\(Pakistan\)"), the large-scale
[nationalization](/wiki/Nationalisation_in_Pakistan "Nationalisation in
Pakistan") of industries and nationwide [census](/wiki/Census_in_Pakistan
"Census in Pakistan") were carried out in 1972.[190] The
[Constitution](/wiki/Constitution_of_Pakistan "Constitution of Pakistan") was
promulgated in 1973 that reflected this equal balance and a compromise between
[Islamism](/wiki/Islamism "Islamism") and [Humanism](/wiki/Humanism
"Humanism"), and provided guaranteed equal human rights to all.[191] The
[military](/wiki/Pakistani_military "Pakistani military") was heavily
reconstructed and heavily reorganised, with President Bhutto appointing chiefs
of staff in each inter-service, contrary to [C-in-Cs](/wiki/Commander-in-chief
"Commander-in-chief"), and making instruction on human rights compulsory in
the military syllabus in each branch of inter-services.[192]:62–100 Major
investments were directed towards modernising the navy.[104]:100 The
military's [chain of command](/wiki/Chain_of_command "Chain of command") was
centralized in [JS HQ](/wiki/Joint_Staff_Headquarters_\(Pakistan\) "Joint
Staff Headquarters \(Pakistan\)") led by an appointed [Chairman joint chiefs
committee](/wiki/Chairman_Joint_Chiefs_of_Staff_Committee "Chairman Joint
Chiefs of Staff Committee") to coordinate the combined and well-integrated
military efforts to safeguard the nation's defence and unity.[192]:62–63 In
addition, Pakistan sought to have a diversified foreign policy, as Pakistani
geostrategists had been shocked that both China and the United States provided
limited support to Pakistan during the course of the war, with the US
displaying an inability to supply weapons that Pakistan needed the
most.[193]:xxxiii

On January 20, 1972, Pakistan under Bhutto launched the [clandestine
development](/wiki/Pakistan_and_its_Nuclear_Deterrent_Program "Pakistan and
its Nuclear Deterrent Program") of [nuclear weapons](/wiki/Nuclear_weapons
"Nuclear weapons") in a view of "never to allow another foreign invasion of
Pakistan."[194]:133–135 This crash program reached parity in 1977 when the
first [weapon design](/wiki/Nuclear_weapon_design "Nuclear weapon design") was
successfully achieved.[195]

### Bangladesh[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Indo-
Pakistani_War_of_1971&action=edit&section=16 "Edit section: Bangladesh")]

Main article: [1971 East Pakistan genocide](/wiki/1971_East_Pakistan_genocide
"1971 East Pakistan genocide")

As a result of the war, East Pakistan disintegrated and became an independent
country, [Bangladesh](/wiki/Bangladesh "Bangladesh"), as the world's fourth
most populous Muslim state on 16 December 1971.[159]:xxxv Pakistan itself
secured the release of [Mujibur Rahman](/wiki/Mujibur_Rahman "Mujibur Rahman")
from the [Headquarter Prison](/wiki/Headquarter_Jail "Headquarter Jail") and
allowed him to return to Dacca. On 19 January 1972 Mujib was inaugurated as
the first [President of Bangladesh](/wiki/President_of_Bangladesh "President
of Bangladesh"), later becoming the [Prime Minister of
Bangladesh](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Bangladesh "Prime Minister of Bangladesh")
in 1974.[159]:xxxv

On the brink of defeat in around 14 December 1971, the media reports indicated
that the Pakistan Army soldiers, the local [East Pakistan
Police](/wiki/East_Pakistan_Police "East Pakistan Police") they controlled,
[_razakars_](/wiki/Razakar_\(East_Pakistan\) "Razakar \(East Pakistan\)") and
the [_Shanti Committee_](/wiki/East_Pakistan_Central_Peace_Committee "East
Pakistan Central Peace Committee") carried out [systematic
killings](/wiki/1971_East_Pakistan_Intellectuals_massacre "1971 East Pakistan
Intellectuals massacre") of professionals such as physicians, teachers, and
other intellectuals,[196][197] as part of a [pogrom](/wiki/Pogrom "Pogrom")
against the [Bengali Hindu](/wiki/Bengali_Hindus "Bengali Hindus") minorities
who constituted the majority of urban educated intellectuals.[198][199]

Young men, especially students, who were seen as possible rebels and
recruiters were also targeted by the stationed military, but the extent of
casualties in East Pakistan is not known, and the issue is itself
controversial and contradictory among the authors who wrote books on the
pogrom; the Pakistani government itself denied the charges of its involvement
in 2015.[200][201][202]:511–512 [R.J. Rummel](/wiki/R.J._Rummel "R.J. Rummel")
cites estimates ranging from one to three million people killed.[203] Other
estimates place the death toll lower, at 300,000. Bangladesh government
figures state that Pakistani forces aided by collaborators killed three
million people, raped 200,000 women and displaced millions of
others.[204][205]

According to the authors Kenton Worcester, Sally Bermanzohn, and Mark Ungar,
Bengalis themselves killed about 150,000 non-Bengalis living in the
East[206]:111 There had been reports of Bengali insurgents indiscriminately
killing non-Bengalis throughout the East; however, neither side provided
substantial proofs for their claims and both Bangladeshi and Pakistani figures
contradict each other over this issue.[207]:108[208]:133 Bihari
representatives in June 1971 claimed a higher figure of 500,000 killed by
Bengalis.[209]

In 2010, the Awami League's government decided to set up a
[tribunal](/wiki/International_Crimes_Tribunal_\(Bangladesh\) "International
Crimes Tribunal \(Bangladesh\)") to prosecute the people involved in alleged
[war crimes](/wiki/War_crime "War crime") and those who collaborated with
Pakistan.[210] According to the government, the defendants would be charged
with [crimes against humanity](/wiki/Crimes_against_humanity "Crimes against
humanity"), [genocide](/wiki/Genocide "Genocide"), murder, rape and
arson.[211]

According to John H. Gill, there was widespread polarisation between pro-
Pakistan Bengalis and pro-liberation Bengalis during the war, and those
internal battles are still playing out in the domestic politics of modern-day
Bangladesh.[212] To this day, the issue of committed atrocities and pogroms is
an influential factor in the [foreign
relations](/wiki/Bangladesh%E2%80%93Pakistan_relations "Bangladesh–Pakistan
relations") between Pakistan and Bangladesh.[213]

## Impact[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Indo-
Pakistani_War_of_1971&action=edit&section=17 "Edit section: Impact")]

### Pakistan: War Enquiry Commission and War
prisoners[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Indo-
Pakistani_War_of_1971&action=edit&section=18 "Edit section: Pakistan: War
Enquiry Commission and War prisoners")]

Main articles: [War Enquiry Commission](/wiki/Hamoodur_Rahman_Commission
"Hamoodur Rahman Commission") and [Indo-Pakistani War of 1971 Prisoners of War
Investigation](/wiki/Indo-Pakistani_War_of_1971_Prisoners_of_War_Investigation
"Indo-Pakistani War of 1971 Prisoners of War Investigation")

In the aftermath of the war, the [Pakistani
Government](/wiki/Pakistan_Government "Pakistan Government") constituted the
[War Enquiry Commission](/wiki/Hamoodur_Rahman_Commission "Hamoodur Rahman
Commission"), to be headed by the [Chief
Justice](/wiki/Chief_Justice_of_Pakistan "Chief Justice of Pakistan")
[Hamoodur Rahman](/wiki/Hamoodur_Rahman "Hamoodur Rahman"), who was an ethnic
[Bengali](/wiki/Bengali_people "Bengali people"),[214] and composed of the
[senior justices](/wiki/List_of_Justices_of_the_Supreme_Court_of_Pakistan
"List of Justices of the Supreme Court of Pakistan") of the [Supreme Court of
Pakistan](/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Pakistan "Supreme Court of Pakistan").[214]
The War Enquiry Commission was mandated with carrying out thorough
investigations into the intelligence, strategic, political and military
failures that causes the defeat in the war.[215]:44

The War Commission also looked into Pakistan's political and military
involvement in the [history of East Pakistan](/wiki/History_of_East_Pakistan
"History of East Pakistan") that encompasses 1947–71.[215]:44 The [First War
Report](/wiki/Hamoodur_Rahman_Commission_Report "Hamoodur Rahman Commission
Report") was submitted in July 1972, but it was very critically opined and
penned on political misconducts of politicians and the military interference
in [national politics](/wiki/Politics_of_Pakistan "Politics of
Pakistan").[216]:22–197 Written in moral and philosophical perspective, the
First Report was very lengthy, but provided accounts that were unpalatable to
be released to the public. Initially, there were 12 copies that were all
destroyed except for the one that was kept and marked as "[Top
Secret](/wiki/Top_Secret "Top Secret")" to prevent the
[backlash](/wiki/Backlash_\(sociology\) "Backlash \(sociology\)") effects on
the demoralised military.[217]:127 In 1976, the [Supplementary
Report](/wiki/Hamoodur_Rahman_Commission_Report "Hamoodur Rahman Commission
Report") was submitted that was the comprehensive report compiled together
with the First Report; this report was also marked as
[classified](/wiki/Classified_information "Classified information").[218]

In 2000, the excerpts of the Supplementary Report were leaked to a political
correspondent of Pakistan's [_Dawn_](/wiki/Dawn_\(newspaper\) "Dawn
\(newspaper\)"), which the _Dawn_ published together with _[India
Today](/wiki/India_Today "India Today")_.[219][220] The First Report is still
marked as classified, while the Supplementary Report's excerpts were
suppressed by the news correspondents.[221]:288–289 The War Report's
supplementary section was published by the Pakistan Government, but it did not
officially hand over the report to Bangladesh despite its requests.[222])

The War Report exposed many military failures, from the strategic to the
tactical–intelligence levels, while it confirmed the looting, rapes and the
unnecessary killings by the Pakistan military and their local agents.[223] It
laid the blame squarely on Pakistan army generals, accusing them of
debauchery, smuggling, war crimes and neglect of duty.[224] The War Commission
had recommended [public trial](/wiki/Public_trial "Public trial") of Pakistan
Army generals on the charges that they had been responsible for the situation
in the first place and that they had succumbed without a fight,[225] but no
actions were ever taken against those responsible, except the dismissal of
chiefs of [the Pakistan Army](/wiki/Gul_Hassan_Khan "Gul Hassan Khan"),
[Pakistan Air Force](/wiki/Abdul_Rahim_Khan "Abdul Rahim Khan"), [Pakistan
Navy](/wiki/Muzaffar_Hassan "Muzaffar Hassan"), and decommissioning of the
Pakistan Marines.[219][225]

The War Commission, however, rejected the charge that 200,000 Bengali girls
were raped by the Pakistan Army, remarking, “It is clear that the figures
mentioned by the Dacca authorities are altogether fantastic and fanciful," and
cited the evidence of a British abortion team that had carried out the
termination of "only a hundred or more pregnancies".[226][214][227] The
Commission also claimed that "approximately 26,000 persons (were) killed
during the action by the Pakistan military"[226][228] Bina D'Costa states that
the War Commission was aware of the military's brutality in East Pakistan, but
"chose to downplay the scale of the atrocities committed."[226]

The second commission was known as [Indo-Pakistani War of 1971 Prisoners of
War Investigation](/wiki/Indo-
Pakistani_War_of_1971_Prisoners_of_War_Investigation "Indo-Pakistani War of
1971 Prisoners of War Investigation"), conducted solely by the Pakistani
government, that was to determine the numbers of Pakistani military personnel
who surrendered, including the number of civilian POWs.[229] The official
number of the surrendered military personnel was soon released by the
Government of Pakistan after the war was over.[229]

### India: Indo-Pakistani Summits[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Indo-
Pakistani_War_of_1971&action=edit&section=19 "Edit section: India: Indo-
Pakistani Summits")]

Main articles: [Agreement Between the Government of India and the Government
of the Islamic Republic of Pakistan on Bilateral
Relations](/wiki/Simla_Agreement "Simla Agreement") and [Transfer of
Population Under the Terms of the Delhi Agreement](/wiki/Delhi_Agreement
"Delhi Agreement")

On 2 July 1972, the [Indo-Pakistani summit](/wiki/Indo-Pakistani_relation
"Indo-Pakistani relation") was held in [Simla](/wiki/Simla "Simla"), [Himachal
Pradesh](/wiki/Himachal_Pradesh "Himachal Pradesh"), India where the [Simla
Agreement](/wiki/Simla_Agreement "Simla Agreement") was reached and signed
between [President](/wiki/President_of_Pakistan "President of Pakistan")
[Zulfikar Ali Bhutto](/wiki/Zulfikar_Ali_Bhutto "Zulfikar Ali Bhutto") and
[Prime Minister](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_India "Prime Minister of India")
[Indira Gandhi](/wiki/Indira_Gandhi "Indira Gandhi").[230] The treaty provided
insurance to Bangladesh that Pakistan recognised Bangladesh's sovereignty, in
exchange for the return of the Pakistani POWs.[98] In mere five months, India
systematically released more than 90,000 war prisoners, with Lieutenant-
General A.A.K. Niazi being the last war prisoner to be handed over to
Pakistan.[98]

The treaty also gave back more than 13,000 km² of land that the Indian Army
had seized in Pakistan during the war, though India retained a few strategic
areas, including [Turtuk](/wiki/Turtuk "Turtuk"), Dhothang, Tyakshi (earlier
called Tiaqsi) and [Chalunka](/wiki/Chalunka "Chalunka") of [Chorbat
Valley](/wiki/Chorbat_Valley "Chorbat Valley"),[231][232] which was more than
804 km².[233][234][235] The Indian hardliners, however, felt that the treaty
had been too lenient to President Bhutto, who had pleaded for leniency,
arguing that the fragile stability in Pakistan would crumble if the accord was
perceived as being overly harsh by Pakistanis and that he would be accused of
losing Kashmir in addition to the loss of East Pakistan.[31] As a result,
Prime Minister Gandhi was criticized by a section in India for believing
Bhutto's "sweet talk and false vows", while the other section claimed the
agreement to be successful, for not letting it to fall into "[Versailles
Syndrome](/wiki/Treaty_of_Versailles "Treaty of Versailles")” trap.[236]

In 1973, India and Pakistan reached another compromise when both countries
signed a trilateral agreement with Bangladesh that actually brought the war
prisoners, non-Bengali and Pakistan-loyal Bengali bureaucrats and civilian
servants to Pakistan.[237] The [Delhi Agreement](/wiki/Delhi_Agreement "Delhi
Agreement") witnessed the largest mass [population
transfer](/wiki/Population_transfer "Population transfer") since the
[Partition of India](/wiki/Partition_of_India "Partition of India") in
1947.[238]

### Bangladesh: International Crimes Tribunal[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Indo-
Pakistani_War_of_1971&action=edit&section=20 "Edit section: Bangladesh:
International Crimes Tribunal")]

In 2009, the issue of establishing the [International Crimes
Tribunal](/wiki/International_Crimes_Tribunal_\(Bangladesh\) "International
Crimes Tribunal \(Bangladesh\)") began to take public support. The tribunal
was formally established in 2010 to investigate and prosecute suspects for the
genocide committed in 1971 by the Pakistan Army and their local collaborators,
_Razakars_ , _Al-Badr_ and _Al-Shams_ during the Bangladesh Liberation
War.[239]:169

## Long-term consequences[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Indo-
Pakistani_War_of_1971&action=edit&section=21 "Edit section: Long-term
consequences")]

  * [Steve Coll](/wiki/Steve_Coll "Steve Coll"), in his book _[Ghost Wars](/wiki/Ghost_Wars "Ghost Wars")_ , argues that the Pakistan military's experience with India, including [Pervez Musharraf](/wiki/Pervez_Musharraf "Pervez Musharraf")'s experience in 1971, influenced the Pakistani government to support [jihadist](/wiki/Jihadist "Jihadist") groups in [Afghanistan](/wiki/Afghanistan "Afghanistan") even after [the Soviets left](/wiki/Soviet_withdrawal_from_Afghanistan "Soviet withdrawal from Afghanistan"), because the jihadists were a tool to use against India, including bogging down the Indian Army in [Kashmir](/wiki/Kashmir "Kashmir").[240][241]
  * After the war, Zulfikar Ali Bhutto authorised the highly secretive and clandestine [atomic bomb program](/wiki/Pakistan_and_weapons_of_mass_destruction "Pakistan and weapons of mass destruction"), as part of its new [deterrence policy](/wiki/Pakistan_and_its_Nuclear_Deterrent_Program "Pakistan and its Nuclear Deterrent Program"), to defend itself and never to allow another armed invasion from [India](/wiki/India "India").[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] Many Pakistani scientists, working abroad at the [IAEA](/wiki/International_Atomic_Energy_Agency "International Atomic Energy Agency") and [European](/wiki/Netherlands_and_weapons_of_mass_destruction "Netherlands and weapons of mass destruction") and [American](/wiki/United_States_and_weapons_of_mass_destruction "United States and weapons of mass destruction") nuclear programmes, immediately returned to what remained of Pakistan and participated in making Pakistan a [nuclear power](/wiki/Pakistan%27s_nuclear_weapons "Pakistan's nuclear weapons").[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]
  * Writing about the war in _[Foreign Affairs](/wiki/Foreign_Affairs "Foreign Affairs")_ magazine, Zulfikar Ali Bhutto stated "There is no parallel in contemporary history to the cataclysm which engulfed Pakistan in 1971. A tragic civil war, which rent asunder the people of the two parts of Pakistan, was seized by India as an opportunity for armed intervention. The country was dismembered, its economy shattered and the nation's self-confidence totally undermined."[242] This statement of Bhutto has given rise to the myth of betrayal prevalent in modern Pakistan. This view was contradicted by the post-War Hamoodur Rahman Commission, ordered by Bhutto himself, which in its 1974 report indicted generals of the Pakistan Army for creating conditions which led to the eventual loss of East Pakistan and for inept handling of military operations in the East.[219]

## Timeline[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Indo-
Pakistani_War_of_1971&action=edit&section=22 "Edit section: Timeline")]

  * 7 March 1971: Sheikh Mujibur Rahman declares that, "The current struggle is a struggle for independence", in a public meeting attended by almost a million people in Dhaka.
  * 25 March 1971: Pakistani forces start [Operation Searchlight](/wiki/Operation_Searchlight "Operation Searchlight"), a systematic plan to eliminate any resistance. Thousands of people are killed in student dormitories and police barracks in Dhaka.
  * 26 March 1971: Sheikh Mujibur Rahman signed an official declaration of independence and sent it through a radio message on the night of 25 March (the morning of 26 March). Later Major Ziaur Rahman and other Awami League leaders announced the declaration of independence on behalf of Sheikh Mujib from Kalurghat Radio Station, [Chittagong](/wiki/Chittagong "Chittagong"). The message is relayed to the world by Indian radio stations.
  * 27 March 1971: Bangladesh Force namely Mukti Bahini consisting Niyomito Bahini (Regular Force) and Gono Bahini (Guerilla Force) was formed under the Commander-in-Chief (C-in-C) General Muhammad Ataul Gani Osmani.
  * 17 April 1971: Exiled leaders of Awami League form a provisional government.
  * 3 December 1971: War between India and Pakistan officially begins when West Pakistan launches a series of [preemptive air strikes](/wiki/Operation_Chengiz_Khan "Operation Chengiz Khan") on Indian airfields.
  * 6 December 1971: East Pakistan is recognised as Bangladesh by India.
  * 14 December 1971: Systematic elimination of Bengali intellectuals is started by Pakistani Army and local collaborators.[198]
  * 16 December 1971: Lieutenant-General A. A. K. Niazi, supreme commander of Pakistani Army in East Pakistan, surrenders to the Allied Forces (Mitro Bahini) represented by Lieutenant General Jagjit Singh Arora of Indian Army at the surrender. India and Bangladesh gain victory.
  * 12 January 1972: Sheikh Mujibur Rahman comes to power.

## Military awards[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Indo-
Pakistani_War_of_1971&action=edit&section=23 "Edit section: Military awards")]

### Battle honours[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Indo-
Pakistani_War_of_1971&action=edit&section=24 "Edit section: Battle honours")]

After the war, 41 [battle honours](/wiki/Battle_honour "Battle honour") and 4
[theatre honours](/wiki/Theatre_honour "Theatre honour") were awarded to units
of the Indian Army; notable among them are:[243]

### Gallantry awards[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Indo-
Pakistani_War_of_1971&action=edit&section=25 "Edit section: Gallantry
awards")]

For bravery, a number of soldiers and officers on both sides were awarded the
highest gallantry award of their respective countries. Following is a list of
the recipients of the Indian award [Param Vir Chakra](/wiki/Param_Vir_Chakra
"Param Vir Chakra"), Bangladeshi award [Bir Sreshtho](/wiki/Bir_Sreshtho "Bir
Sreshtho") and the Pakistani award [Nishan-E-Haider](/wiki/Nishan-E-Haider
"Nishan-E-Haider"):

India

Recipients of the Param Vir Chakra:[244][245]

  * [Lance Naik](/wiki/Lance_Naik "Lance Naik") [Albert Ekka](/wiki/Albert_Ekka "Albert Ekka") (Posthumously)
  * [Flying Officer](/wiki/Flying_Officer "Flying Officer") [Nirmal Jit Singh Sekhon](/wiki/Nirmal_Jit_Singh_Sekhon "Nirmal Jit Singh Sekhon") (Posthumously)
  * Major [Hoshiar Singh](/wiki/Hoshiar_Singh "Hoshiar Singh")
  * [Second Lieutenant](/wiki/Second_Lieutenant "Second Lieutenant") [Arun Khetarpal](/wiki/Arun_Khetarpal "Arun Khetarpal") (Posthumously)

Bangladesh

Recipients of the Bir Sreshtho:[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

  * Captain [Mohiuddin Jahangir](/wiki/Mohiuddin_Jahangir "Mohiuddin Jahangir") (Posthumously)
  * Lance Naik [Munshi Abdur Rouf](/wiki/Munshi_Abdur_Rouf "Munshi Abdur Rouf") (Posthumously)
  * Sepoy [Hamidur Rahman](/wiki/Hamidur_Rahman "Hamidur Rahman") (Posthumously)
  * Sepoy [Mostafa Kamal](/wiki/Mostafa_Kamal_\(Bir_Sreshtho\) "Mostafa Kamal \(Bir Sreshtho\)") (Posthumously)
  * ERA [Mohammad Ruhul Amin](/wiki/Mohammad_Ruhul_Amin "Mohammad Ruhul Amin") (Posthumously)
  * Flight Lieutenant [Matiur Rahman](/wiki/Matiur_Rahman_\(military_pilot\) "Matiur Rahman \(military pilot\)") (Posthumously)
  * Lance Naik [Nur Mohammad Sheikh](/wiki/Nur_Mohammad_Sheikh "Nur Mohammad Sheikh") (Posthumously)

Pakistan

Recipients of the Nishan-E-Haider:[246][247]

  * Major [Muhammad Akram](/wiki/Muhammad_Akram "Muhammad Akram") (Posthumously)
  * [Pilot Officer](/wiki/Pilot_Officer "Pilot Officer") [Rashid Minhas](/wiki/Rashid_Minhas "Rashid Minhas") (Posthumously)
  * Major [Shabbir Sharif](/wiki/Shabbir_Sharif "Shabbir Sharif") (Posthumously)
  * [Sarwar](/wiki/Sarwar "Sarwar") [Muhammad Hussain](/wiki/Sawar_Muhammad_Hussain "Sawar Muhammad Hussain") (Posthumously)
  * [Lance Naik](/wiki/Lance_Naik "Lance Naik") [Muhammad Mahfuz](/wiki/Muhammad_Mahfuz "Muhammad Mahfuz") (Posthumously)

## Civilian awards[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Indo-
Pakistani_War_of_1971&action=edit&section=26 "Edit section: Civilian awards")]

On 25 July 2011, Bangladesh Swadhinata Sammanona, the Bangladesh Freedom
Honour, was posthumously conferred on former Indian Prime Minister Indira
Gandhi.[248]

On 28 March 2012, [President of Bangladesh](/wiki/President_of_Bangladesh
"President of Bangladesh") [Zillur Rahman](/wiki/Zillur_Rahman "Zillur
Rahman") and the [Prime Minister](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Bangladesh "Prime
Minister of Bangladesh") [Sheikh Hasina](/wiki/Sheikh_Hasina "Sheikh Hasina")
conferred Bangladesh Liberation War Honour and Friends of Liberation War
Honour to 75 individuals, six organisations, [Mitra Bahini](/wiki/Mitra_Bahini
"Mitra Bahini") and the [people of India](/wiki/Indian_people "Indian people")
at a special ceremony at the [Bangabandhu International Conference
Centre](/wiki/Bangabandhu_International_Conference_Center "Bangabandhu
International Conference Center"), Dhaka. This included eight heads of states:
former [Nepalese President](/wiki/President_of_Nepal "President of Nepal")
[Ram Baran Yadav](/wiki/Ram_Baran_Yadav "Ram Baran Yadav"), the third [King of
Bhutan](/wiki/King_of_Bhutan "King of Bhutan") [Jigme Dorji
Wangchuck](/wiki/Jigme_Dorji_Wangchuck "Jigme Dorji Wangchuck"), former Soviet
Presidents [Leonid IIyich Brezhnev](/wiki/Leonid_Brezhnev "Leonid Brezhnev")
and [Nikolai Viktorovich Podgorny](/wiki/Nikolai_Viktorovich_Podgorny "Nikolai
Viktorovich Podgorny"), former Soviet Prime Minister [Alexei Nikolaevich
Kosygin](/wiki/Alexei_Kosygin "Alexei Kosygin"), former Yugoslav President
[Marshal Josip Broz Tito](/wiki/Marshal_Josip_Broz_Tito "Marshal Josip Broz
Tito"), former [UK Prime Minister](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_the_United_Kingdom
"Prime Minister of the United Kingdom") [Sir Edward Richard George
Heath](/wiki/Edward_Heath "Edward Heath") and former [Nepalese Prime
Minister](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Nepal "Prime Minister of Nepal")
[Bishweshwar Prasad Koirala](/wiki/Bishweshwar_Prasad_Koirala "Bishweshwar
Prasad Koirala"). The organisations include the [BBC](/wiki/BBC "BBC"),
[Akashbani (All India Radio)](/wiki/All_India_Radio "All India Radio"),
[International Committee of the Red
Cross](/wiki/International_Committee_of_the_Red_Cross "International Committee
of the Red Cross"), [United Nations High Commissioner for
Refugees](/wiki/United_Nations_High_Commissioner_for_Refugees "United Nations
High Commissioner for Refugees"), [Oxfam](/wiki/Oxfam "Oxfam") and [Kolkata
University](/wiki/University_of_Calcutta "University of Calcutta") Shahayak
Samiti.

The list of foreign friends of Bangladesh has since been extended to 568
people. It includes 257 Indians, 88 Americans, 41 Pakistanis, 39 Britons, 9
Russians, 18 Nepalese, 16 French and 18 Japanese.[249][250]

## Dramatization[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Indo-
Pakistani_War_of_1971&action=edit&section=27 "Edit section: Dramatization")]

Films

  * _[Border](/wiki/Border_\(1997_film\) "Border \(1997 film\)")_ , a 1997 [Bollywood](/wiki/Cinema_of_India "Cinema of India") [war film](/wiki/War_film "War film") directed by [J.P.Dutta](/wiki/J.P.Dutta "J.P.Dutta"). This movie is an adaptation from real life events that happened at the [Battle of Longewala](/wiki/Battle_of_Longewala "Battle of Longewala") fought in Rajasthan (Western Theatre) during the [1971 Indo-Pak war](/wiki/Bangladesh_Liberation_War "Bangladesh Liberation War"). [_Border_](https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0118751/) on [IMDb](/wiki/IMDb "IMDb")
  * _[Hindustan Ki Kasam](/wiki/Hindustan_Ki_Kasam "Hindustan Ki Kasam")_ , a 1973 [Bollywood](/wiki/Cinema_of_India "Cinema of India") [war film](/wiki/War_film "War film") directed by Chetan Anand. The aircraft in the film are all authentic aircraft used in the 1971 war against Pakistan. These include MiG-21s, Gnats, Hunters and Su-7s. Some of these aircraft were also flown by war veterans such as Samar Bikram Shah (2 kills) and Manbir Singh. [_Hindustan Ki Kasam_](https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0154591/) on [IMDb](/wiki/IMDb "IMDb")
  * _[Aakraman](/wiki/Aakraman "Aakraman")_ , 1975 Bollywood film set during this war featuring a romantic [love triangle](/wiki/Love_triangle "Love triangle").
  * _[1971 – Prisoners of War](/wiki/1971_\(2007_film\) "1971 \(2007 film\)")_ , a 2007 [Bollywood](/wiki/Cinema_of_India "Cinema of India") [war film](/wiki/War_film "War film") directed by Sagar Brothers. Set against the backdrop of a prisoners' camp in Pakistan, follows six Indian prisoners awaiting release after their capture in the 1971 India-Pakistan war.
  * _[The Ghazi Attack](/wiki/The_Ghazi_Attack "The Ghazi Attack")_ , a 2017 war film directed by Sankalp Reddy. Based on the sinking of PNS Ghazi during the war.
  * _[1971: Beyond Borders](/wiki/1971:_Beyond_Borders "1971: Beyond Borders")_ , a 2017 Indian [war](/wiki/War_film "War film") [drama](/wiki/Drama_\(film_and_television\) "Drama \(film and television\)") film written and directed by [Major Ravi](/wiki/Major_Ravi "Major Ravi") _[251]_

Short Films

  * _Mukti_ \- Birth of a Nation, a 2017 short film directed by Manu Chobe depicts the negotiations between Jacob and Niazi over the Instrument of Surrender.[252]

Miniseries/Dramas

  * _[PNS Ghazi](/wiki/PNS_Ghazi_\(Shaheed\) "PNS Ghazi \(Shaheed\)")_ , an [Urdu](/wiki/Urdu "Urdu") (Pakistani) drama based on sinking of [PNS Ghazi](/wiki/PNS_Ghazi "PNS Ghazi"), [ISPR](/wiki/Inter-Services_Public_Relations "Inter-Services Public Relations")
